text: Friendly and helpful staff - they take care of you here! We only had appetizers and a beer at the bar, but apps were hot and tasty and good beer variety (we are craft snobs). Ran out of one app, manager (owner?) apologized up and down. Super nice folks. Will come back again.

This is what people said: I love this place! They cook the food right in front of you! This is what I thought: Oh, it must be like a hibachi place, kind of fancy, really tasty.  This is what it is like: a cafeteria where you pile raw ingredients into a bowl then line up to have your food schlepped onto a grill where it is cooked to your liking.  OK.  The food is just all right.  The first time I ever went there we made reservations (what did I know? I thought it was a fancy joint!)  the hostess looked at me like I was insane when I walked in and said we had one.  Another time I was there I ordered a gin and tonic...I noticed they had a full bar and I wanted one for whatever reason.  The waitress brought me a RUM and TONIC.  Good Lord.  I don't think anyone in the history of drinking has ever ordered a rum and tonic.  Not really worth the time.  If you're in the area, just FYI, there's a Winking Lizard a few doors down.

I think they should change their name to anything else but Mongolian Grill. I've had much better experience with Mongolian Restaurant in different cities, and I think it's a bit misleading to call it that if you are not going to stand up to its standard. I am not trying to be a hater here, but I believe that everything authentic tastes much better than the wannabes. I mean, I would be so sad if I were a Mongolian to find out about this place.
For example, the rice doesn't taste good, and rice is a staple food in most Asian cuisine and every Asian restaurant should know how to cook good quality rice (seriously, I never complain about rice ever.. and how hard is it to cook decent rice?). The taste of the meat that you pick and got cooked over a big circle grill?? Dissapointing with a capital D. THe sauce choices were so Americanized, and even the soy sauce tastes weird. 
In addition to those, I think it's overpriced, and you have to keep paying extras for additional meat, etc.

Ive been coming to this place since I was in high school. We came then for the all you can eat, build your own/ season and spice your own menu, and I still go there now post workout for some protien overload. For something like 15$ your can build an all meat monster, or a nice balanced asian dish. Its nothing classy or fancy, but the guys that grill your food can do some wicked tricks and its fun and different to watch your food get cooked. Fun meal for the guys night out, not so much for dates.

This is just like most bd's thay are scattered around the country. They have your standard selection of meats and veggies. They have a good selection of sauces and seasonings. The chefs are very good at preparing the food which came to me everything very fresh and extremely tasty.

If you have never come here before the waiter will explain to you how the do-it-yourself meal works. Its certainly very gin either to go by yourself or with a group of friends.
BD'S Mongolian never fails. Atmosphere is always great. Food is good and experience is always fun. If you're in Coventry look to Bd's.

My family and I came here for a birthday celebration. There was a normal than longer wait, which is to be expected during peak hours. However, upon inquiry as to the current status of our wait, we discovered we were skipped in line and lost our spot. This resulted in us having to wait additional time. We were completely understanding of the situation. However, the hostess became especially annoyed and was verbally rude to my family and I. While the food was good, the service initial service was disappointing. Our waiter Anthony was very nice and hustled to get us our drinks. The overall experience with management was disappointing and appalling to the point we will not be returning.

Wish they would put up hand sanitation dispensers near the meat station.  I can literally feel the salmonella transfer from tong to digit after every trip to the meat bar.  They also need somewhere for people waiting to get their food cooked to place bowl and the ramekin of sauce so they can stand there on their phones and pretend not to listen to the people cooking.  I feel like this business model could be in a food court and this way I wouldn't have to get meat slime on my hand when I am dining out.

4:00pm and the place is 80% empty. The guy tried to seat me at a little tiny table. I asked can I sit at a bigger table? I'm a pretty big guy and I joked with him that I was wider than the table, and I am, not huge but big enough to feel crowded. He comes back and asks "Can you just sit there?" I said "Really? You're about to loose me here, I thought I asked nice, I'm fat, can I please just sit at one of the many empty tables?" So he let me sit at a different table. Shouldn't have to ask twice. 
The waitress then came over with a little tiny bowl and explained how to get the raw food and they'll cook it, etc... 
I said, "ok, I'm getting the all-you-can-eat, I'll need more than that little bowl." She said I can have another bowl after finishing with this one. I tried to explain, look, I'm a big guy, I'm gonna eat 4 or 5 of those little bowls at least, can you please just bring me a few to get started? 
No. 
I said if I can't keep the food coming this could take me all night. I'm here to eat. That's not the way it works she says. I said That's not a very good deal, I don't think I'm gonna do it. She rudely snatches the bowl away and snobbishly says fine as she storms away. 
I was a little rude after that but WTF!!!
If you're gonna offer all-you-can-eat you should expect a few big eaters now and then. It's Rude and Ignorant to discriminate and not graciously offer a comfortable seat and access to the so called all-you-can-eat food in a timely manor without a snotty rude waitress. Never did try the food. Never will. Don't be deceived, if you like to chow down this is not the place. Another place that thinks I would go out to follow their stupid rules they have set up to regulate my food intake at an all-you-can-eat. It doesn't work like that. This place will never last.

This is a fun place to go for any type of occasion.  The service fluctuates very much, however.  As a very frequent customer I have seen both immaculate service and absolutely dreadful service.  They are usually pretty busy on the weekends, especially at night.  You should try and call ahead for availability and wait time.  Hopefully the hostess answering the phone is not rude- one time I was appalled as I inquired about a fairly large group on a busy night then got hung up on.  Thinking it was a fluke I had a friend of mine try to call and the same thing happened to her.  We ended up not going there that night.  

The food is good, you basically build your own bowls with the option of using their recommended meal cards... Which  I never do.  I am always sure to stack my bowl up high and experiment with different sauces and seasonings.  The grill staff is usually very entertaining although when crowded there is a lot of congestion and confusion surrounding the grill.  The rice and tortillas supplied to the table is a pleasant addition to the cooked meal.  The waiters are not always the best at refilling drinks, rice, and tortillas, however.  

The cleanliness can sometimes also be a concern. I caution those with allergies as cross contamination is very possible with the sloppiness of some people when creating their bowls.  I have been there on some days when the counter was covered with various meats, vegetables, and sauces.   Some days, however, it is sparkling clean.  

Ultimately, this is a safe joint to go to if you are looking for a fun, different dining experience.  Be warned that service and cleanliness fluctuate- you never know what you are going to get from either on any given day.  Not the best place in the world but certainly a good place to frequent.

I've been coming to this location for over 10 years but the last few trips have been very disappointing. This weekend we tried again and had incredibly slow service even though the server was only bringing us water and fresh bowls. All our food tasted the same no matter what sauce or spice bc they weren't cleaning the grill well in between diners. Not to mention the lack of cleanliness. It was frustrating to see 5-6 people hanging around the host stand and another few waiters standing at the drink station when the place was a disaster. Huge chunks of food all over there floor, sauce on the counter where customers waited and tons of unbussed tables. It was clear the employees don't care so we will not be returning.

Just wasn't good. 
There was hair in the raw meat. 
When trying to select what I wanted, there were about 5 men reaching over me to get what they wanted.
I'm not tall, also not super short (5'4") and it was so difficult to see what food they had set out. 
The staff on the grill were very friendly. 
But just blah food.

This place is great!! Just be sure that you know what you are getting in for before you go, so that you are not disappointed. This is the place to go when you want a loud, interactive, fun meal. Do not go here if you want a quiet sit down dinner night, with people waiting on you hand and foot!

I personally had a great time here. Their selection of meat (duck! calamari! scallops!), veggies, and sauces was out of this world. The lines to get your food grilled weren't too bad, but know in advance if you are going there on a Saturday, you will wait about 10-15 minutes for your food to be cooked. That is just the way it is - it is a busy place! The cooks fry up everything on a big circular grill, and it is a lot of fun to watch them. They are interactive with the guests, and will cheer you if you give them a tip :) 

You will also get a big birthday song if you go for your birthday.

The waiter was exceedingly polite and cheery too.

Yes, it is one of 'those' places! Go prepared to have fun, be loud, and interact with the staff, and you will have a great time. If you don't want a whole restaurant singing to you, just stay home and go another night when you are in the mood for a louder, more raucous experience. You will have a much better time that way!
Great as always food we love it here! Kielbasa and ribeye steak are the way to go service could be better at times but you can beat the food

This was my very first BD's Mongolian Grill experience and it just may be my last... A friend and I were in Cleveland this weekend for the Browns game. We stayed near the Museums (which is kind of near the main Medical Centers) because we wanted easy access to them before the game. There were no restaurants close to the hotel so we took a shuttle to Coventry Rd. to eat...that's when things started going downhill...

We got to the restaurant, first thing I noticed was how dirty the floors were...gross. I never-minded it and we got seated. The first bowls they brought us out were filthy. We were both chipping pieces of dried food off of them. Being that it was my first time there and I really wanted to make my own stir-fry I shrugged it off and proceeded to make my food. When I got back to the table my friend had gone to the soup and salad bar...he said that it was disgusting, and then showed me a dirty spoon, soup bowl and plate...at that point we had both completely lost our appetites. 

I told the waiter about it, and he then sent the manager over to speak with us. They were very understanding and did not charge us for our meal. I was just very disappointed for having always heard about how great it was and how delicious the food is supposed to be.

Booooo!  I am so disappointed in the Southside Works for wasting prime reality on this place.  A friend of mine suggested we go here for dinner the other night and let me just say I was underwhelmed and "skeezed" out.  If I had known this was basically an "Old Country Buffet" disguised as actual Mongolian food, I would have aggressively suggested somewhere else to go.  Also, I didn't realize it was a corporate chain either; I find a lot of value in the Cheesecake Factories of the world, but in general I don't get real excited about chains or franchises. 

Ok that said; let me say what was good about the place:

1) Healthier options
2) Friendly and enthusiastic staff

On to the negative stuff:

1) It's a buffet!
2) Our waiter, clearly instructed by his management, had about a 10 minute opener listing all the rules and health code regulations when using the buffet line. Overkill much?
3) The place was relatively messy.  Sauces spilled everywhere, food bits hanging around on the floor, dirty tables, etc.  I think this is to be expected when you have your customers doing the majority of the food service for you.
4) The barriers on the buffet line were sparse, I felt like everyone going through the line was breathing all over the food. NOT APPETIZING
5) The menu is all over the place. They offer Asian, Italian and American ingredients; these are paired with recipe cards that you are advised to follow.  Way too complicated and no real cohesiveness to the theme or style of food.
6) In order to get your food you must huddle around a large grill with about 15 other patrons while they cook your food.  This is a novelty that I think most people will endure once.
7) They offer a "salad" bar with the all you can eat option, the salad bar stinks.  It's brown iceberg and some other random under temp veggies on ice.  The soup is so ridiculous as well, obviously frozen Campbell's Select or something of the like.

So um yeah, this was far from the worst place in Pittsburgh, but I won't be going back.

While the food was ok, and the guys that were cooking the food were nice, I'm not happy with the overall experience. My boyfriend and I went there on a weekday, and they were very understaffed and overcrowded. It's not that service was bad, there just was not enough of it. 

- We ordered egg rolls, and they came out rather late. 
- I dropped my fork by mistake when I first got my food and asked for a new one, but was not brought a new one until the meal was long done and we were waiting for our check. I didn't mind that too much, because I ended up using chopsticks.
- My water glass was empty for most of the meal.
- The tables/seats were so close to each other, I noticed people struggling to walk around. I was so close to the table behind us, I got headbutted by the guy sitting behind me, and I was sitting with my midsection squished against the table. In addition, when I attempted to walk up to the area where they cook food(to get myself chopsticks), I got elbowed by a girl trying to take her coat off while sitting at her table. There was just no room to get around. 

I left with a headache(from colliding heads with the guy behind me, the uncomfortably loud noise level due to too many people seated so near to each other all talking, and not enough water), not happy, and still hungry(we were planning on getting dessert there, but ended up leaving and getting it elsewhere). 

I love going out to eat, and was hoping that this place would be another regular spot(because I love the idea of this place). With all of the other options available around Pittsburgh(especially South Side), I have no reason to go back. There is much better experiences elsewhere.

The meal I had at bd's mongolian grill was amazing.  The ability to create your own meal and have it prepared for you with excellent entertainment is awesome.  It has a great family atmosphere and its welcoming to all. Needless to say I will be back.
Very good service.   Nice atmosphere.   Good fresh food.   First time here.   I would recommend it.   If you like Mongolian BBQ.

Sister dragged me down on a Monday afternoon. Not liking the crowds in South Side anyway, was only convinced by a free meal.
     Wasn't crowded at all and sat immediately. My nephews had to fill me in on how it worked. Easy. Being in a wheelchair was easy to maneuver around. Stuffing things you liked in one bowl was difficult without overflow. Was a nice change of deciding how much of this and that. 
     I had gotten the pork, noodles, and a bunch of others (too many to list).  I really enjoyed watching the guys cook on the rounded flattop. Another customer stated sometimes they put on a show, but I missed out.  A few minutes later I was digging into a heap of goodness. The one bowl did me justice, but as for my nephew, he got seconds.

My plate tasted like char. 
I'm never coming here again. It tasted so strongly of char that I had to cover the entire thing in hot sauce.

The best experience anyone could have, great food with the cooks doing tricks with the cook ware, nice friendly environment, reasonably priced, YEP YELPERS this place is great, and it's a must go to spot if you live in Cleveland...it's the best!

Disappointing considering the buzz I've been hearing. Food was okay and I liked the fact that there were so many choices but that's about it for the highlights. I've honestly experienced better atmosphere in a high school cafeteria. The restaurant is like one big mess hall! Rows of brown tables and chairs, no dividers, no decor, no greenery, no wall art, nothing! Just tables, chairs and people. 

The experience itself was very stressful especially with a young child. Having to select your food whilst juggling a toddler and then waiting in line whilst juggling said  toddler plus bowls of food and sauces, and then to having to wait again whilst watching your food cook is not my idea of a relaxing dinner out. 

Prices seemed a little high and I did not like the fact that, even though we ordered the 'unlimited' bowl, we had to wait (and wait, and wait) for our server to bring us additional bowls. We also had to wait (and wait, and wait) for rice and when we did get it, you would have thought there was a rice shortage! Skimy, skimpy...and we never did see him again to ask for more.

Restaurant was very noisy, gong banging every 5 minutes, servers hooting and hollering at one another and I swear they must have spilled, broken, and/or dropped at leat 10 different drinks while we were there. Maybe it was just a bad night...

The food, once I could actually eat it, was decent (in a fast food sort of way), the selection was nice, and the huckleberry iced tea was delisch!  Not sure I will be going back in a hurry...just too extremely stresssful in my opinion...and they have some work to do. Like better description of sauces, combo suggestions, speeding things up at the grill or finding a better method for 'crowd control' and for the love of all things holy...have trays available for carrying bowls, sauces, entree plates, etc.
Went here for lunch because its close to work.  Loved the food being cooked right in front of me!  The place was crowded but service was good.  Definitely will go again!
I took my lunch here i like it is different than others you can choose your food by your self and they will cooked it in front of you

Sat in an empty dining room for 15 minutes waiting for someone to acknowledge us or take our order.

Scratch that. They didn't even have to "take our order," they just had to hand us two bowls for a buffet. That's it.

I'd totally accept the amount of time we had wait if it was busy, but there was maybe 2 other groups in the entire restaurant.

I have been to this location a few times over the last 10 or so years. Always a 15-25 minute wait time. I have to say the quality and selection of the food has gone down, while the prices have gone up. The concept is you take an empty bowl and load whatever food and sauces in it and some dudes cook it in front of you. But unless you're one of those people who really likes to eat until you explode (or a college kid) it's not really worth it... their one plate vs. unlimited plate option is only a few dollars more. The guys that cook the food are usually funny and very polite, but the "wait staff" are often cold, slow and seem like they don't really want a job. So if you want to cram down mediocre food for an expensive buffet price with lousy wait staff just to see some dudes cook your food in front of you, this is the place!

Add an "a, to "bd" and thats what you get, bad service. We love the concept and the food is good, but our server was horrible. After bringing our initial water we did not see hIm agaIn for nearly an hour. We finally flagged down another server to get our bill and go. I don't know where our server went but my guess is they sent him to Mongolia for more Sauces or spices. Not the service I'd expect when a place is slow on a Sunday night.

My family will return again and again.

Kids meals are all the same price.  My kids opted for the bowl instead of the menu fare.  Really nice because even for picky kids, there are so many choices.  

I tried two different bowls while there with the brown rice.  Everything was prepared perfectly.  There was nothing I didn't like - because I chose all the ingredients.  My husband equally loved his dishes.  

The staff was very helpful and attentive.  They could ease up a little on the upselling, but I understand they were trained that way and the staff is still learning the ropes.  I was a little put off by our waiter bringing the desserts to the table and offering them to my kids without asking us first.  I would not have let my children have dessert if I had been ask but it was already in front of them so I didn't want to start a battle in the restaurant.

I caution people with ANY food allergies.  They use utensils on multiples peoples dishes at one time.  If someone has a severe egg, seafood, peanut allergy, they could be exposed.

This restaurant has the worst servers. Not only are they rude, but it seems they enjoy being rude together. The managers come on a revolving door, the supervisors on duty are young & unprofessional. When calling for take out, because I actually enjoy the food, I am always hung up on. Always. I call back several times. I walk over to place an in person order and THERE ARE NO CUSTOMERS! Why then can you not take a to-go order without hanging up on the patron? ok, so third try, place an online order...foods wrong? oh even though I have a print out, from the actual order, somehow its my fault? Again, geez. I always feel they enjoy being rude. Like a clique of young rebels. I am sure they'll even be proud of this review, and the manager (who's "new") wont do anything about it.

Terrible service, OK Mongolian stir fry. Waited 10 minutes for drinks, then asked about them, waited another 5 before they came. Kid's meal arrived cold. Sent it back and waited another 15 minutes for a new one. After we had our stir fry and were eating for 5 minutes I had to flag down a server to get rice because our waitress was nowhere to be found. Now we've been done for 10 minutes with no drinks and no check so I decided to alleviate my boredom by writing this review. Won't be back.

How is it that no one has reviewed this place yet?!  Every time I come home to Ohio I have to go to Mongolian for shrimp, scallops, noodles, and veggies in black bean and peanut sauce.  

Here's how it works:
You take a bowl up to a huge bar filled with various meats, fish, chicken, pork, noodles, and vegetables.  You fill up your bowl with everything you want and move on to the sauces and spices.  You can then mix and match any sauces and spices you want.  Again, I go for the black bean and mix it with peanut.  Add a dash of cayanne, garlic, ginger, or whatever and you're off to the grill.  

The grill is a big circular contraption where grillers with long sticks cook your stir fry just the way you want it.  There's also a salad bar and good soups and killer deserts (try the carmel apple sundae!).

This place is fun, the grillers are cool and do fun tricks with the sticks and shout when they get a tip and you hit a gong.  What more could you want!?  

Also, a great after dinner walk down to the Big Fun and a stop a Stricklands for frozen custard is a great way to end the evening.

Have I mentioned I love Mongolian BBQ?

Great location, style, and options for a unique dining experience.  BD's has long been a great option for me when I'm feeling like I want to have a massive meal.  I've toured multiple locations in Ohio and Colorado to say the least.

This location had friendly staff, great service but I'm concerned about the lack of cleanliness as I can also attest to seeing cockroaches at this location as John has mentioned in a previous post.

Friendliness only goes so far in hospitality and it most certainly won't stop you from getting sick.  I hope they remedy the situation before it's too late.

Maybe they are trying to keep the Cleveland movie filming business rolling and are ploying for a sequel to Joe's Apartment II.

I was disappointed with my first trip to BD's. I do not have one near where I live, so I went to this one when I recently was out of town for a Steelers game. I have heard many people rave about BD's so I was excited to make my first trip there. The service was good, the cooks were friendly, the restaurant was clean, the prices were descent. My big problem was the quality of the food. The shrimp they had were literally about the size of a penny. The steak they had, at least after it was cooked, reminded me of steak ums. The chicken was decent, the had imitation crab. The vegetables and sauce were normal, nothing to write home about. I wouldn't even mind paying more if the quality of the protein was better, basically it's a glorified create your own stir fry joint. I wouldn't go back, which is sad, because this place does have potential.

A friend was celebrating a birthday the other day so twenty of us showed up to help celebrate. Their restaurant of choice was BD's, so, after making a reservation, we all gathered in the upper section of the place. This all happened on a Tuesday night so we didn't find it overly crowded. The main idea of BD's is: you are given a bowl and anything you can get into the bowl will be what is grilled for your meal. You gather your "mix" at a kind of salad bar, except it contains meats, veggies, sauces and spices. Stack as much of it as you want in your bowl and that's the makings of your meal. Proceed on over to the grill, take a place at a numbered spot (so they can tell whose meal is whose) and it will take about five minutes to cook. If you are vegan or vegetarian, tell them and they will put up a little barricade to keep anything from the adjoining cook-spot from drifting over into your food. Hint: everyone gets a bowl of white or brown rice, lettuce wraps or tortillas, so skip the noodle stuff and concentrate on the "good" stuff.

It was my first time at BD's, it not being anywhere near where I live or hang out, so I had to kind of learn as I went and it was a bit confusing. One of the first things at the "bar" were eggs. I thought they were hard boiled, so skipped them. They are not. Grab one or two and the cooks will scramble them right into your meal. Fill your sauce cup up if you actually want to taste the sauce. And go easy on the spices.

The One Bowl of Stir-Fry goes for $9.99. Add $1.50 for Unlimited Soup and Salad Bar. Add another $1.50 for Unlimited Stir-Fry. The evening I was there, one of the soups was a creamy roasted root vegetable with tomato chunks. It was some of the best soup I have ever eaten! Honestly, I went back for three helpings. Stirred in a little rice and it became a meal in itself.

Overall no one complained, and there was much praise for BD's Mongolian Grill.The staff was as helpful as it gets, answering any questions and even going to grab an egg for one of our group who, like me, thought they were hard boiled and neglected to select one. Parking is probably a little iffy in the Coventry area, especially on busy weekends, but I found a spot on the street just around the corner across from the theater. Even though it is part of a small chain that extends mostly through the Midwest, I understand why BD's is a local favorite.

I've been here several times.  It's s fun place to go.  You pick your own meat, veggies, and sauce and they cook it up for you, right in front of you! You have the option of one plate or for $2 more you can get all you can eat.  There's no waiting, which I love! They can also handle big groups, but make sure to call ahead.  They have a nice drink and dessert menu.  I think they are only lacking on the kids menu.  The portions are super small and my niece and nephew were still hungry after eating.  The prices are fair.  If you are looking for a change from the normal restaurant experience you should check this place out.

Not good.  Go elsewhere!  The whiny and very loud alternative music seems at odds with the type of food they are serving.  The service is slow and the cooks are terrible and rude.
As for the food...the shrimp were macerated and unrecognizable but the beef and chicken were good.  The sauces were unique and interesting.  The noodle and veggie selection was adequate.  There was plenty but a few staples (like mushrooms) were noticeably absent.  There was also too much American/Mexican food.  The soups were Poblano Cheese and some sort of Mexican corn.  Pasta, meatballs, and marinara were available on the menu as well as red sauce.  Not very Mongolian...  Yout money is best spent elsewhere.

Food is good but expensive. Yes you can load your bowl and I loved they cook it in front of you but still a little pricey for the size of the bowl. Can be packed at times and the only thing I didn't like had nothing to do with the restaurant itself but, I hate how people reach over you when you are in the line to "load your bowl"

I LOVE BD's.

This is the second year in a row we've celebrated my birthday there and we will continue to do so.  It's such a fun place!  We always get the unlimited bowls because I like to try different combinations and for $3 extra it's totally worth it in my book.  They'll also give you a to-go box so it's great to make an extra bowl and then take it with you for lunch the next day.

Our server was super friendly and she kept our water glasses full and replenished our rice twice (each table gets white and brown rice to accompany their stir-fry).  The selections on the stir-fry bar were plentiful and well-stocked.  My favorite combo is sirloin, scallops, lo-mein, tons of veggies, fresh garlic, and a combination of bbq and hot chili sauce.  SO delicious.

We didn't order anything from the bar this time but their drinks are usually strong and well-priced.

This is a great place for a group and perfect for picky eaters.  We'll be back for sure!
I would recommend this to anyone. The food is great... well if you know what you are doing(build your own bowl). Endless food is on $2 more than the standard price. Come hungry and eat well.

Really love the concept of this place. The only thing a little off is that the sauces were a little spicier (if you follow the recipes) than expected. Okay for me, but some people don't like that spicy. Like the way the food is cooked on the hot stone. Fries eggs on a hot stone...gotta try it if you've never had it before! I like the veggie selection best.

First time going here was a few weeks ago... First time ever having bbq!
Really fantastic!!! Wonderful staff, incredibly delicious food.. I'll be coming back here every time I'm near Coventry!

I love the idea of walking through the bar and picking out the ingredients you want in your stirfry, because sometimes you see things that you wouldn't initially think to add. You then take it to the chef and he fries it up for you while you wait, which in my experience doesn't take that long.

I used to go all the time as a kid, and loved it. My food was always delish. But when I got older and came here on a date, I added entirely too many meats and they clashed horribly with each other. Which of course, is my fault.

As for the service, I'd say below par. It wasn't crowded at all when we went (I don't remember the time of day) but our server only came to check on us twice. It was pricey, but because we added so many things to our stirfry.

Overall, I would go again, being way more careful of my combination and a little more money in my pocket.

Fun place to go to! Huge portions, super cheap, yummy, nice staff. 
So basically you can fill up a bowl with all the meat/veggies/sauces that you want. Then they will grill it in front of you with all the ingredients you put into the bowl. Once they cook it, you'll be surprised at how much food you have in front of you... definitely worth!


Tip:
-scan the bar first to see what you want 
-don't fill your bowl too much at the beginning 
-just keep stacking lol

The food was decent but the overall experience is not. The process of creating your bowl is not fun and is very difficult to manage if you have small children in tow. The place was also a mess with virtually every point being point being dirty. We have no intention of ever returning again.

This restaurant is barely worthy of one star. They leave raw food sit out on a buffet. They have a very large disk where they attempt to cook your food. Mine wasn't fully cooked and I got food poisoning. I'm never coming back EVER.

Visits: Once, for lunch.

Before I start, I'll just say that it's a 2-star Chinese, 3-star Asian fusion place. I'll try to be as objective as I can, but the preface is that I'm not fond of Americanized Chinese food. I thought it would be like some of the normal, non-chain Mongolian grill. Turns out that it's like the PF Chang's of Mongolian grills - maybe even a little less authentic.

Food: Mongolian grills are Taiwanese-style food with Southern Chinese style sauces and ingredients, but I've come to expect that and enjoy them for what they are. That said. This was something of a travesty. The salad bar was puny and not worth existence. There were two soups - beef mushroom and beer cheese, both super creamy. Not a Chinese style soup or salad in sight. Couldn't they at least make some facsimile of a Chinese soup?

Then there were the seasonings. Oh god, shall I get started on those? None tasted like Chinese sauces I've ever had, barring soy sauce, which was, y'know, soy sauce. Some were supposed to be something (like the black bean sauce, which didn't really taste like doubanjiang should). Okay, fine. I get that maybe some people really love their fajita sauce or barbecue sauce (wtf?) on their "Chinese" grill. But at least put out some Chinese staple seasonings! Garlic, ginger, chili powder, and soy sauce were the only staples of Chinese flavorings they had. Meanwhile, there were a lot of seasoning varieties of the completely left-field variety - rosemary? Mixed herbs? "Seasoned salt"? "Cajun"? WTF? Where's the cumin? Where's the ground red peppercorns? Where's the sesame oil?

When I go to a Chinese (or "Mongolian") restaurant, I'm in the mood for Chinese food, or at least "Chinese" food. This was neither. It's some "fusion" cuisine. I wouldn't usually mind, but they don't directly advertise themselves this way, and I left there dissatisfied.

I'm taking two points off for the rating because it advertises as though it's something Chinese/Mongolian, not a fusion place. As a fusion restaurant, it'd only get one star off (for not really incorporating enough Chinese flavors). I get that it wasn't for me. If you're looking for Americanized Asian fusion food, this isn't a bad place to go, food-wise. The vegetable selection is pretty great, and there's a ton of flavorings to choose from. And at least there's he fen. There should always be he fen.

Atmosphere: Eh, typical atmosphere for this kind of restaurant - a kind of Chiptole crossed with a casual sit-down. No real comments here.

Service: We ordered the unlimited stir-fry, salad, and soup lunch. Even though there was exactly one other pair of customers in the entire restaurant, we somehow ended up having to wait for her to come over with new bowls. Maybe it's because she was chatting with the people over at the bar.

The person on the grill that day was hardly nice, either. She's standing in a semi-circle counter. We approached her from the right, after having filled our bowls, and make eye contact and smile. We get to the counter. She gestures us to the left side of the counter, despite only needing to turn 90 degrees to face us and pick up our bowls. The same thing happened every time we approach her and she's not directly facing us; sometimes it was on the left, sometimes it was on the right, so it's not that some of the counter wasn't being used. I don't mind walking over, but when you have food pickup areas labeled on the entire semi-circle, it's kind of weird to be gestured all around, seeming because the person manning the grill doesn't want to turn around or walk two steps.

Between the two of them, that's a point off.

Cost/Benefit: At around $12 per person for AYCE that has scallops and snow peas, it's a decent enough deal.

Bottom line is that if you're looking for Asian fusion cuisine, it's an average restaurant. If you're looking for anything remotely authentic, look elsewhere.

I just recently had a meal here and wow did it hit the spot. Our waitress was very patient given how busy it was and, as we were a moderately sized party, very effectively attended to our needs. I also found the establishment to be clean and well kept. In fact my only gripe would be that the bowls were too small to accommodate my overly anxious eyes and appetite as I wanted to grab everything I saw at the self-service bar. This was rather minor though considering the selection, variety, portion size, taste, and overall feeling of satisfaction all at a very reasonable price.

I am a Pitt student who dined in at Mongolian Grill. Long story short: I would have rather gotten stir-fry from the university's dining hall, Market Central. If you're not a student it costs $13 and it's all you can eat and so much better than Mongolian Grill, which is saying A LOT.

There were a number of issues with my experience at Mongolian Grill:
1. The stir-fried rice was crunchy. Seriously, I felt like I was eating burnt Rice Krispies cereal. It was so bad that I did not get the unlimited bowl, however, others in my party did just because they could not eat their first. Moral: avoid the rice.
2. The waitress was somewhat incompetent. She forgot to bring us our sides of rice until we were halfway through our meals, and then charged me for the wrong (and more expensive) dessert, and refused to change it.
3. The soup and salad bar were awful. The soup had separated, so there was grease and oil on the top, and there were bacon bits in the bins that had fruit and other salad toppings. I feel bad for any vegetarian or vegan trying to enjoy a meal here.
4. The manager is sketchy. After speaking to him about being over charged, he offered to give me free meal coupons (uh, not after that food!). Once I refused, he offered to mail me cash... Isn't that illegal? Despite me paying with a credit card, he said he could not refund me, which makes no sense.


I rarely leave bad reviews but after the disrespect I faced from the manager, I felt no other choice. I am a foodie who doesn't mind spending money on food, but I truly regret spending $20 at this establishment. You're better off going to the Cheesecake Factory across the street. Seriously.

ok, so it's a stirfry place where they cook it on a big ol' grill in the round.

and yeah, i've heard some people have not had the greatest experiences here during non-peak hours.

but i LOVE this place.  

make what you want.  if you suck as a recipe concoctor (yep, i just made that up) then go back and make another one.

fun.  fun times.

I've always been interested in this place and was ultimately pretty disappointed by it. It's a pretty confusing experience, if it's your first time. 

So first of all, there's no pre-determinded menu. You need to create anything and everything on your own. It's kind of like cooking at home, but doing the difficult part on your own. 

How about you take this little bowl and try to pile as much crap in it as possible? And also make sure you understand how all of the raw ingredients will cook together on the skillet. 

The place is pretty dirty and sticky and the waitstaff was very unpleasant. The cooks are oddly demanding about exactly and only where you stand. And finally, it's overpriced when it's a glorified cafeteria. 

Not a fan.

I love going to BD's! It doesn't get crowded for lunch, but it does get pretty crowded for dinner every time I've been there. You can pay for either one bowl or you can pay a price for unlimited number of bowls. There are three buffet like stations. The first one has all the raw meat/fish, you can mix meat, everything is how you want it. Next, they have vegetables and eggs you add to the meat, and then lastly you grab a small bowl and go to the sauce station. They have a variety of about 20 sauces, again you can add as many as you'd like, behind the table they have suggestions on what sauces taste good together and what style of sauce they are. You can then add any spices to your bowl if you want. Next, you take it to a hibachi type center, where the cooks take your bowl and cook it right there in front of you, they take multiple people's at once, you just wait there until your bowl is done. There's a salad and soup bar also for an added price. You also can either get rice or tortilla wraps to go along with your bowl. They only thing I don't like about Bd's is that the raw meat can get on the handle and can get on your hands, and that's a little bothersome, they do have hand sanitizers around the buffet tables, but that does bother me....I definitely recommend to anyone to try Bd's Mongolian Grill!

Came in on a Saturday afternoon with the most finicky of eaters, my mother. Her idea of letting her hair down at lunch is to get a Big Mac- plain!

As we entered the serving line, the apparent pain on her face while scanning the raw meats was priceless. As she was contemplating a fast retreat and the more positive option of going hungry, Rob the manager strolled by and offered to help. 

Rob and mom went to work, starting with chicken and then adding her favorite vegetables, broccoli, corn, carrots and potatoes. Rob hung back while she made her choices, but then quickly moved back in when she got to the sauces.   With no idea of what to do, Rob swooped in with suggestions. Do you like hot or mild?  Sweat or tart?  They settled on an orange sauce and then let the grill masters do the work. 

She was surprisingly pleased with her dish and actually had to force out 'I like it!'  Everyone else had great meals too and we will come back anytime we're in the neighborhood.

Where to start? Walked in. Realized that this place was somewhere between TGI-Fridays and cheap stir fry. Quite a low point to start at. Went to sit at the table only to realize that all of the lights on our side of the restaurant  were annoyingly blinking, such that one might be concerned about having a seizure. Next, we were asked about drinks and appetizers. Drinks took very long and we didn't really know what to do from there because we did not yet have bowls. When we realized that a redonkulous $14 + dollars would get us a teeny bowl in which we were told to fill with an assortment of raw meats and veggies. The look of raw meat prior to a meal was quite unappetizing. I had to strategically place veggies into my bowl because it was so tiny after I filled it with a couple noodles. We then waited in line for our meager meal to be cooked on a grill. Oh and by the way, you can't move more than 5 inches without an employee asking if you need help. I mean its a glorified buffet, not brain surgery... Anyways, meal was cooked on the grill between several cooks. This is the part that concerns me regarding food borne illness. While one meal was placed on the grill, the cook would saut√© that meal and then move onto the next, which also had raw meat in it. Just something about seeing the cooks touch raw meat then touch my cooked food, did not seem OK. Regardless, because I love food, I ate my meal anyway, albeit while listening to horrid top 40 dance/pop music blaring. Not a whole lot of food if you get just one bowl. Did I mention it was over $14? I had a glass of wine and a bowl of food.... $23. REALLY?

Overall WAYYYY over priced. But we did get a free beer coozie as we left. Perhaps my expectations were too high. This place will probably do alright for the typical buffet goers who gorge themselves. But if you actually enjoy the TASTE of food and not the feeling of being engorged, I would roll to another place in South Side that serves stir fry for half the price.

I used to like this place but its change a little and it's still a little good haven't been there for a couple months or so Davidson argument about birthday club and everything so we just haven't gotten back

This just isn't my type of place. We had sections of our dining halls set up to be something like this and I enjoyed those better. Create your own stir fry, create your own pasta, create your own burrito. It all just makes more sense to me when it's in a college dining hall. But to go out and pay for someone to cook something that I made up and that might not taste so delicious seems silly. At least at the dining hall, I could toss my mistake and come back for more without regret. (Granted, you could probably get away with that here, but I'd feel too bad.) 

I'd rather go somewhere with a chef that puts together some masterpiece with flavors that are going to mix well. I'm no chef and I don't claim to be; I think everything sounds good, then I can't make up my mind, then things end up making me lose my appetite! Plus, all of the meats sitting out in jiggly bowls makes me feel weird.

Stopped by at BD's with a group of high school kids on a dinner while we went shopping at the southside mall. I am a philadelphian at heart, so the burg is pretty new to me. The general atmosphere of the restaurant is good, waiters are efficient and speedy. We all picked the bowl option, where you pick meats, vegetables, pasta, tofu, and various sauces/spices to be pan seared/fried into a dish. This option costed $13.50, but I think bowl refills were rather inexpensive. 

PROS: There were a huge variety of things to put in your plate, including various types of strip steak, seafood (scallops and stuff), chicken, and marinated meats. There were also many vegetables, and tons of unique sauces, including peanut, soy sauce, asian, chinese black bean, etc. The chefs do tricks with the cooking tools while they are preparing your dish, which is cool. 

CONS: The bowls are rather small and the portions were not very good for the initial price, but if you are extremely hungry the bowl refills are cheap. Some meat was not cooked fully as I wanted, but still edible. Some meat was greasy, but the entire dish was actually quite good. It's fun to try different sauces and spices. 

So all in all, yes I would go here again just to try different combos and such, but the small portions and steep initial price were the two biggest drawbacks. It's definitely cheaper than the Cheesecake Factory nearby, so grabbing some quick lunch or dinner is the best option.

I took my boyfriend here on a date & I must say the manager Ben was excellent. He provided great customer service, personally cooked my food on the grill & made sure we had the best experience. not to mention the food was amazing. Definitely a happy customer & will go back!!

Atmosphere was very inviting and staff was very welcoming. First time so it was weird to adjust to the process and that caused a lot of last minute adjustments. I can't believe I missed the salad bar but my meal was very filling. The last star was because one of our guest had a seafood allergy and it took more than 2x to correct his food preparation, by then we all we're done without meals.

BD's is a favorite place for me to bring kids. You create your own meal, watch it cook, and then hit a gong -- what's not to like?

The meat is fresh and the the vegetables are crunchy. I like mixing the sauces. A couple of times my mix was just awful. No worries. I got to create another meal. 

My husband and I go to BD's when we just want a fun night out. After all, we like to hit the gong too.
Very yummy. Like how you can pick the meat veggies and sauces. Shrimp was a little fishy tasting though. Will be back

Ok where do I start? I must admit I ruin my first experience here because I didn't have a clue what to do. Although the waitress was very pleasant she  was pretty vague on instructions for a first-timer.Therefore, I made the mistake of completely  filling my bowl up with meat. leaving no room for veggies.In her defense,she offered me another bowl for veggies,no charge. That's when she thoroughly explain how to select meat,veggies and sauces which is very tricky because they all looked delicious. Positive my next visit will be better now I think I got the gist of it.However my meal wasn't a total debacle the chili garlic sauce I choose was outstanding. The guys stir fried dish to perfection,didnt overcook. Cant wait to go back, I got a few delicious ideas for next meal. will be back soon.

Love it here and in this cold and rainy icky day here in Cleveland, this seemed perfect. We went early and perhaps around 1pm. No crowd and the whole experience was great. I am a fan of any of the seafood stir fry and that's what I ordered . My kids are big fans of and beef and chicken combo and ordered that. For the price, it's so good. I had the one bowl and it was 9.95 and the endless bowl was 13.95- such a great price . I don't know how anyone can eat endless bowls of Mongolian , but that's me. Overall, very good and love getting lettuce with mine to make it super low carb.

The all you can eat setting was good and so was the veriety. Everything turned out to a satisfactory setting until you add souse. They recomend to get a little cup of souse and hand it to the grillers. But if you put it in pior then the cooks will burn your food. The cooks only know how to use the sauses after the food is cooked and not before. In adition it seems that the way the grill is cleaned needs some work other than a spray of oil and a scraper. Its good food at a good price, just remember when eating there if you dont get your combination just right to the grillers expectaions then you will end up with what looks like leftovers from the grill trap.

The location is great and parking after 6pm is free. Friendly atmosphere and a good selection of food. They could use an additional cook there were only 2 working the grill at the time we were there. I had dinner with my wife daughter and best friend. They mixed up the sauces and spices that my wife and I had and our tastes are very different. I would go back but watch the cook a little closer next time.

Not for vegetarians!!!

Over all I actually do like the food here.  The service is also great and for what amounts to an all you can eat buffet with the entertainment value of the food being stir fried right in front of you I would say it's reasonably priced.

The place appears to be vegetarian/vegan friendly.  If you don't want meat just skip that section and move on to the veggies.  If you tell them you are vegetarian they will clean the grill and make sure someone else's meal doesn't touch yours on the grill.

Vegetarian friendly, right?

Wrong!!!

Disclosure: I am not a vegetarian but I used to be.

While getting my bowl ready I noticed a big piece of raw meat (either chicken or pork) in the minced jalape√±os.  This really didn't phase me because I had raw meat in my dish to get cooked anyways so who cares.

Someone that is a strict vegetarian would definitely care.  When I pointed this out to the guy that was stocking the ingredients he promptly plucked it out and went on about his business.  The jalape√±os weren't swapped out they just removed the raw meat.  Again, as a meat eater this doesn't really effect me.  As someone who was a very struck vegetarian (even vegan at one point) this is unacceptable.  What's it matter if the take extra time to separate your food from the others if the veggies you selected are tainted with raw meat?

Obviously the knuckle dragging idiot that managed to drop it in there in the first place is the cause of all this and it makes me wonder what else might end up in your bowl but I don't think the worker handled it correctly once it was pointed out.  

This isn't exclusively a problem here but any self serve all you can eat buffet.  It just seems the average patron to these types of places is pretty ignorant when it comes to maintaining cleanliness and avoiding cross contamination so it does fall on the establishment to police this.  I have yet to find one that actually does.

Stir-fry is not my thing especially in this fast food setting.   Let's start with the pros of this place.  They have a bar with great drink specials, the staff are friendly and helpful enough, and the food looks tasty once it is cooked.  

The cons for me outweigh the pros as I am not sure how sanitary this place is. They have a ton of raw meat of all varieties in a salad bar setting.  How can you ensure the proper tongs are used by people or people aren't touching their raw meat with the veggie tongs? This place gets very crowded and you could have to wait a while to get your food cooked.  To start, you are given a small bowl to top with as much meat, pasta, rice and veggies as you would like. The meats range from chicken, beef tips to crab and salmon.  You have every kind of veggie possible to add as well.  Once you bowl is filled you take it to be cooked.  There are also a ton of sauces you can get mixed in.  The unlimited bowl (go up as many times as you want) is $17.99 which is a bit pricey but if you are hungry you could certainly get your money worth. Since I am not a fan of stir fry I went with the soup and salad bar option which is $7.99 ($6.99 for lunch).  The two soup options were tomato parmesan and chicken tortilla. Both were very tasty and they chicken tortilla soup had a spicy kick to it.  The salad bar did not have a ton of options but enough for a hearty salad.

This place never disappoints me. When I went here a few years ago I did not like the inconsistence of the food they had but recently they have expanded their food options and it seems as though they are consistent with the food options. Anyways I love their food and I love creating my own dish. Also theur brownie sundae dessert is tasty!!!

The guys at the grill are talking about going down to the flats to sell "white" to the politicians. Food would be much better if the grill was clean. Horrible service by employees who cat call pretty girls and hate their jobs. This place has gone really down hill recently.

Been coming here for years. Hasn't changed very much. If you can get past the fact that people are breathing all over raw meat that you're about to slop into a bowl to get cooked and then eat it, then it's great.

There is ample parking across the street in the parking garage, or if you're lucky you can find some on the street.

They have some pretty decent tasting alcoholic drinks - but they're not very strong - I know what do I expect when I order a Strawberry Daiquiri?

There's something for everyone at Mongolian - meatitarians, vegetarians, etc.  They offer a variety of meats, tofu, and even veggie patties. The sauces are my favorite part. Chili Garlic, Mongolian Ginger, Peanut, & Pad Thai are my favorites.

They do call ahead seating for larger groups - so that's helpful. Otherwise on a weekend I'd expect to wait 25-30 minutes or more for a table.

One last thing - I've learned less is more @ Mongolian. It's only 2 extra bucks for another bowl (which if I'm not mistaken might be unlimited) so you don't have to load your bowl CRAZY full of meat like I've seen some folks do. And don't go super crazy on the sauces - some of them are quite spicy!

I like this place and this concept and on top of it the price.  If you've never been here I highly suggest it at least once.

BD's is a do it yourself with a little help all you can eat protein/vegetable/sauce party with a chef show in between preparation and eating.  Here's 10 steps to how you eat here...

1. Get a bowl
2. Pick a protein 
3. Pick a vegetable 
4. Reverse step two and three if you're experienced
5. choose a sauce or mix of sauces and spices
6. take it to a strict customer line up to get cooked
7. Watch the show and talk to the people around you
8. Order rice or wraps or nothing
9. eat it
10. repeat all you can

Go for lunch and total it's $20 a person drink and all.  The alcohol is priced fair and the staff is always interesting and helpful. Well worth any money spent for what you get.  Highly recommended.

I had a craving and so we went to try it out.  I was sorely disappointed.  
GOOD: Offers a huge selection of ingredients and spices, and flavoring sauces; if you know what you like or what the flavors are, then you should do fine - if you're unsure, you're sunk the descriptions are nice, but for the inexperienced it would be easy to make a mess of things. 
BAD: They burnt our meals (a little water at the beginning of cooking would be beneficial).  The "bacon fried rice" was really gross, the bacon had to be the CHEAPEST (oscar mayer?) bacon I've ever tasted in fried rice.  Seriously.  
They say they'll make it right if something isn't right ... we ate what we could, paid, and left.  This is not a place I'll return to most likely.
Yeah I get the selection is great and such and the diversity and all, but honestly for the price I could've gone to a hibachi, got a show, and gotten the same thing for around the same money ... with more space, too (our seats kept bumping against those around us, and we're not large people). Our server was attentive and somewhat helpful in explaining.

what's not to love? the meats and seafood are fresh. as are the veggies. the combinations of sauces and seasonings are endless. if you don't like your meal you've only got yourself to blame. 

wait, i thought of one thing not to love. you're probably going to eat too much and hate yourself later. if you don't hate yourself, your colon will. 

still, it's worth it. you must check it out.

I like it, the food tastes good, and it's a cool concept.

But they're not very clear on what to do and where to go to with the plates.  And it's not very clear how much stuff costs, like is a side of rice included?

Went yesterday having not been there for about a year or 2. I was very dissapointed, quality has declined while prices have increased. I understand the price increase, but service was bad and the grill team was weak. Was seated in the bar area had to wait about 15 minutes before even being acknowledged, then had to wait longer for a server from a different section to take our order... just wanted a bowl and waters, all while the bartender served the other tables in our section and made a long island for a walk in that sat at the bar. We came back with our food only to find black crispys from a poorly bricked grill and no silverware or napkins on our table. There are a multitude of options down south side for food and I can safely say I will not choose this one again.
Great place to eat when your in Cleveland. Expect 1hr wait most nights. Kids love picking out stir fry items and having them grilled up!

I just recently had my first visit to Mongolian BBQ and it was a different buffet than what I was used. I came on a weekend so It was pretty packed and I had to wait quite a while to be seated but it was no big deal.

Once we were seated I discovered that you put all the food you want on a plate and select your sauce, my usual impulse would be go back to the table and eat but I discovered they have to cooked first. It's a pretty display to see all your food being cooked right in front of you.

The energy of the place was quite lively, the cooks all sang happy birthday to the customers who had a birthday that day and they even tried to get the customers to sing along which most of them did which was nice.

The food they have is pretty tasty, and I liked that they had iced margaritas.  About the only small complaint I had was the selection was pretty limited.

Regardless I enjoyed myself and ate so much that the employees joked about my stomach being a bottomless pit. :)

So let me start off by saying that I've been here three times now and I like it. I do think that the stir fry bowls are overpriced for the little bowls that you're asked to begin with, but the food is good. Also, those three times that I've come here were during happy hour which makes it worth it. The margaritas are super sugary, but you can't beat $3 margs. The apps are delicious from the spinach & artichoke wontons to the dumplings to the fried rice---well worth half off apps! I'll continue coming here during happy hours.

I've been going to this place for about a year now -- and sadly, it really disheartens me to see the way that the tableside service is going -- downhill fast.  The last time that my wife and I were there, we waited fifteen minutes for a server to come to our table for our drink order before leaving -- only to have our server run out to us and mention that he was "In the back doing other things" and couldn't come out to greet us.  The time before that, we had our food at our table for a five or so minutes before our server brought out our drinks, rice, and tortilla shells.  I'll be honest -- I fell in love with this chain when they were in Columbus.  Now, I kinda dread when company comes over and asks to go to BD's for lunch.  With that said, I'll still continue to go -- I can have lamb and have it prepared the way that I like it, but, I've tamed myself down to accept the fact that the service is going to be horrible.

After getting tired of my wife bugging me forever to take her here, we finally went on Mothers Day. I wish I had listened sooner as this place is great! No wait and no need for reservations unlike the Cheesecake Factory across the street which had a 2 to 3 hour wait!

Here's how it works:

1. Once seated a server comes and takes your drinks orders and hands each of you a bowl.

2. You go up to first station, the meat station and add as little or as much chicken, steak, pork, shrimp or imitation crab meat as you want. Ignore the "pick one meat only " sign. You can get all the meat available if you want. There are also lo mein and rice noodles available at the station 

3. Then you go to the vegetable station and add as much spinach, broccoli, snap peas, onions, mushrooms, water chestnuts, tomatoes, carrot and more to your bowl.

4. Next you go to the sauce and seasonings station and pick from over twenty choices.

5. Finally you go over to grill. You will be given a number from 1 to 10. The number you get is were you go and place your bowl and sauce(s) and wait while your food is cooked. Be sure to tip the cooks. They will give you a cheer when you do.

6. And last but not least sit and enjoy. 

Once you have your food your server will offer you white or brown rice, lettuce wraps or tortillas to go with your meal.

One bowl cost $8.99 for adults and $6.49 for kids 3 to 11, but unlimited bowls for adults are just $2 more and the second kids bowl is free. Even if you're full off the first bowl go through again and take it home for lunch the next day.

Our server Luke was great. He explained to us how everything worked. We each started off with a tasty Raspberry Lemon Aid.

For my first bowl I had lo mein, steak, mushrooms, onion, broccoli and yellow, red and green peppers. The cooks were really nice and talked to each person while they cooked there food. They teased us about it being our first time there.
Let me tell you, the food was delicious! Everything was fresh and tasted so good!

For my second bowl I had lo mein, chicken, shrimp, steak, mushrooms, onion, broccoli and yellow, red and green peppers. It was just as good as the first. I could only eat about a quarter of it and took the rest for lunch the next day.

They also offer appetizers and desserts and have a full bar.

Insider tip: Be sure to check in using the Yelp app to get $2 off of a bowl and also to sign up for Club Mongo for future discounts and free meals.

If you are from California, skip this place or you will be disappointed. This place is ONLY worth it if you get the all you can eat for lunch. if you just get one bowl with no unlimited adds, it is way too pricey. Depending on who makes your food you'll be lucky to get the sauce evenly mixed into your food. the first half of my meal was completely lacking in flavor and the second half was drenched in sauce.

On another note, this place is just as Mexican as it is Mongolian. I saw more people eating fajitas with the soggy tortillas than I saw people eating stir-fry.

I really like going to this place. Fun atmosphere and fun staff. 
My only complaint would be that sometimes the soup and salad bar isn't kept up the way it should be. During busy hours it becomes quite messy and no one seems to take care of it. 
Other than that, I'd recommend it. Making your own bowl to be cooked on the grill is fun, and you only put into your meal what you want in it.

if you don't like your meal at Mongolian it's your own fault! tons of options to personalize your stir fry make this chain a fun and delicious experience. 
         our service at this particular location was good and the restaurant was well staffed. pricing here depends on whether or not you get unlimited bowls (3.00 extra) and if you order any other sides. 
         stick with the stir fry and customize your bowl with whatever you like. my brother and I compete to see who can stack their bowl with more food. they offer flour tortillas, lettuce wraps, white rice and brown rice on the side included with your bowl. get these and make tacos! I like to go back up to the sauce selections and bring a couple back to the table for dipping (pro tip). 
         the salad bar is very basic but good as well. it's nice to have this as well as 2 different kinds of soup included in the price of your stir fry bowl. if you have room after a giant bowl of stir fry, a salad and a bowl of soup they have a list of yummy desserts, including deep fried oreos, which you already know are good.

Awesome I've been coming here for years and never had a bad trip. Park in the Marc's parking lot (yeah parking meters in a parking lot how annoying) The staff is always very attentive. Great drinks and dessert too.

In a nutshell: customizable stir-fry, all you can fit in your bowl. Flavors depend on what you put in your stir fry. The contents of your bowl get cooked for you. 

The concept of all you can fit in your bowl sounds great but it doesn't end up being all that much. The bowls are not that big which makes it awkward to put in a lot of ingredients. Not that I'm asking for huge portions but for $14, I'm not sure if that's worth it for a small bowl of stir fry. For $3 more, you can get unlimited bowls. In terms of flavor, it really just depends on what veggies and sauces you put on it so the potential of having a great stir fry is there. It's just without knowing what the sauces taste like, it hard to pinpoint what you'll like. 

I should also note that all the ingredients sit out and there's one buffet that stores raw chicken right next to noodles among other non-meat ingredients. It's all cool that it's raw since it'll all going to get cooked anyway, but the risk for contamination is unnerving. If someone puts the tongs back in the chicken juice and someone else goes to grab that tong and then another tong and another, those chicken juices will be on every tong and spoon. I know I'm quite the germaphobe so I'm sure not many are thinking in terms of contamination, but I definitely recommend washing your hands after the cooks finish your food.
Worthy if you are sea food lover and you have to know what and what not to add to your food. Nice place to give it a try especially if you are really hungry

I have always loved Mongolian BBQ but this time left me feeling rather..."meh". None of my complaints were ever present during previous visits. I hate spicy food. I'm a wimp. I learned after making a heaping pile of food that I'd used siracha chicken instead of Italian chicken as the meats were mislabeled. I also noticed that they didn't chop the veggies up quite as much as they previously did...particularly the green peppers and onions. That's all well and good if there are knives at the table but instead I had to ask for one. A minor annoyance. The food was tasty and service was good. I went to the bathroom and found it to be a train wreck. One of the two stalls was clogged and there was toilet paper and paper towels on the counter and floor. I mentioned it to a server and by the time we were leaving someone was headed in there to clean it. They also fixed the sign on the buffet as well. We will certainly be back and hopefully it's a more positive experience because I love this place!

My husband has been talking about going to this place for a long time. We finally had the opportunity to go when we took a bike ride down to Southside with the intentions of trying this place for a late afternoon lunch. When we arrived, it was pretty empty. We were seated and greeted by a very nice waitress, who thoroughly explained the process and answered all questions we had. 

We hit the soup and salad bar first since that was included in the price. I  tried the Four Pepper Chili which I actually really liked, but it was REALLY spicy! My husband really enjoyed the Root Vegetable Soup. The salad bar was nothing to ride home about but served its purpose. Next, we moved on to the main event, the stir-fry! I love making roasted vegetables at home so this was a cool experience. We were able to pick our raw meat/seafood: I opted for chicken, ham and sausage. Then, we moved on to the vegetables. My dish consisted of broccoli, peas, corn edamame, onions, peppers, etc. The idea is to pile your bowl as high as you can without stuff spilling over! Well, not really the point but it was a fun challenge. Finally, there is a sauce bar where you choose/mix the sauces you would like all of your ingredients to be mixed in. I chose sweat and sour and Korean BBQ with some cajun seasoning and rosemary herb. 

The cooking process: everyone stands at a numbered location and the two cooks go around and ask if there are any allergies and then they begin to cook everything in the bowl. It took about 10-15 minutes so you have to be patient, enjoy the experience. Once it was done, we returned to our seats where our waitress had brought us some brown rice, and we dug in! I thoroughly enjoyed the sausage and I thought the combination of vegetables and seasoning I chose was pretty good! 

We had purchased the one bowl, but there is an option for unlimited bowls. One bowl is plenty for a meal, however the unlimited option would be enticing to try different flavor combinations (as smaller portions of course) but you have to be willing to wait for it to cook each time. 

. Pricing was ok as it is a lot of food and you get to create your own meal. However, this was a fun experience. Food was good, service was good, and we were still able to ride our bikes to The Strip for some ice cream!

Good place to eat.  My favorite part of a Chinese Buffet is always the Hibachi.  This has a lot more options and also more spices and sauces.  Also, they give you lettuce to make your own lettuce wraps, and tortillas if you want too.  Chinese food on a tortilla!?!?  I was skeptical too, but it's pretty good that way.  The price is a bit more than a Chinese Buffet, which is a downside, but when I guess you're not housing all your workers in an apartment and bringing them to work in a van everyday, you have to charge enough to cover wages.  Other reviewers complain that they've been to better Mongolian places in other cities.  Well sure, that may be, but there's better lobster restaurants in Maine, and the only option we have around here, so I say give it a try.

Mongolian BBQ is one of those fun restaurants that really allows you to completely customize your meal.  You pick any ingredients that look appealing and they cook it up for you.  They offer many different meats (shrimp, calamari, scallops, duck, chicken, pork, red meat), vegetables (pretty much every veggie there is), pastas, sauces, and spices.  They combinations are really endless.  When you choose all of your toppings, in the portion size of your own choice, they cook it up for you and send you back to your table with a personally developed concoction to try.

While it is a fun experience, the truth is that you're paying guys $15 to make you a stir-fry that you can make just as easily at home.  The food here doesn't suck by any means because they give you tons of fresh ingredients and you get to make anything you want out of them.  However, you're not likely to have the culinary experience of a lifetime here.  It's likely not going to be any different than something you whipped up at home (that it, if you cook.)

I went here for a dinner celebration with work, and they were able to accommodate our huge group of 20 without a problem.  We had two servers who were very attentive and helpful.  The atmosphere is casual and fun.

Yet, when it comes down to it, I likely will not go here again.  I just don't see the point of spending $15 on this when I can make the same thing at home in my pajamas.

I live in Columbus Ohio and love Mongolian BBQ. We visit them quite frequently, however while on two business trips to Pittsburgh I decided to visit this location. First off, the service was extremely poor on both visits. My first visit it took almost 10 minutes before the waitress even noticed I was sitting there. The restaurants in Columbus when you are seated they ask you for your drink orders and if you want tortillas and rice, when you return from making your first bowl of food, the rice, tortillas and drinks are at the table waiting for you. Not in Pittsburgh, when you come back from making your first bowl you better expect to wait 5-10 minutes before getting your tortillas and rice. Your soda will only have 4-5 cubes of ice and will not be cold. The grillers in Columbus will flip, turn and chop up your meat and veggies on the grill so it cooks evenly and sometimes they even put on a cheerful show or will talk to you while your food is cooking if they're not busy. Not in Pittsburgh, they plop down your food on the grill and that's where it will stay for the majority of the cooking time. They will only flip/turn your food once or twice at the most, and will make no effort to chop up the large pieces of meat and veggies. As a result your food ends up tasting burnt. This restaurant needs a more cheerful customer focused staff and new management BADLY!!!

Went there for the first time and will not go back. The lettuce and toppings at the salad bar were clearly old. The place was messy. The stir fry was average at best. The only part that was good was the service and the cooks. They were all very nice.

I was impressed with the quality and value of the food here! I had never been to a Mongolian grill restaurant but had always wanted to try, and I wasn't disappointed. The set up of the restaurant is either you order a pre made meal off the menu or make your own bowl. I highly recommend making your own bowl because you can add as many of your favorite ingredients that you can fit on the plate. Since I signed up for their email program, I received a $5 off coupon, so I ordered the unlimited bowls. This allowed me to get creative with different flavors and sauces, as well as have plenty of leftovers to bring home. The food was fresh and delicious! There is also a salad and soup bar included and I found that a great addition. The soup was excellent and I went up a few times to refill my salad plate. By the end of lunch I was full and satisfied that I had enough food for 3 more meals with all my leftovers. Just know that they only provide you with one go-to box.

I really like this place.  They have 6 different meats you can choose from and tofu if you want to go vegeterian.  They have all the veggies you want, noodles, and about 20 - 30 different sauces.  All you can eat for 20$ on a weekend night.  Not a bad price considering its location.

The only bad thing is there is always a 45 minute wait on weekend nights.  Not a problem though - put your name down and walk around coventry for a little bit.  Go get a drink at a bar.  Not a bad way to spend your night.

Very Positive Experience 

-Clean Dining Room 
-Prompt Table Service 
-Amazing Selection 
-Super Fun Grill Guys

I give high marks for this one
BD Mongolian Grill is a place for everyone! You pick your ingredients and sauces and the amazing grillers who are quite the showmen grill it. Wonderful time everytime.

Genghis Khan would be proud!  Another great Bday dinner here, always a superb meal!  Had 3 bowls, salad & soup. They have huge selection of proteins, so many sauces too it's amazing.  Newer favs.. Yumyum is good, Orange Peal is delish. Only sorta complaint is place is too busy.  Ha.

I was excited to return here and we had such a good dinner. Watching dinner being prepared on the large grill and picking what you want makes this a fun place. Don't forget to hit the gong to thank them! I opted for 2 bowls and also tried some different ingredients. I just really like the large options that are available.

I really do love this place...

My first experience was during the bomb threat dramz at Pitt. Instead of waiting around for the all clear, our whole staff journeyed down here to stuff our faces. BDs did some recruiting with us before they opened so we figured we'd go check it out. Best decision ever!

You get a bowl, fill it with meat, veggies, rice, pasta- any and everything you can think of. Then you get to pick one of their MANY sauces to adorn your food!

-quick break, I'm drooling-

The worst part is the wait if there are a lot of people and generally watching them cook your food. Give them a tip!  They do fun things when you do (not in the stripper sense...). 

Just go!  And if you're still hungry, just pay $2 more and go all-you-can-eat. My tummy can't handle it, but God bless if you can!

We were quite disappointed in the service this trip. The food was awesome, the cooks did a fantastic job. Our waitress, Uno(?) was terrible. We didn't get our drinks until we finished our salads. She was busy talking with co-workers by their beverage area. Interestingly, the employees were all enjoying their drinks while chatting, ignoring us. We were already back at our table and eating our stir fry when she finally showed up with our rice. Refills on drinks were slow, at best. Also, they highly advertise their Coke offerings with over 100 flavors. Posters all over. I ordered diet Root Beer with vanilla. She forgot the vanilla every time. My wife ordered Orange Pop. She got a diet coke with orange. My wife said it was not what she ordered, and the waitress told her most people who order orange want it in Coke. 
At first I thought she was new. But when Manager showed up in dining room, she suddenly started doing her job. So she knew better and covered herself when she needed to. Sadly shows what the younger college types are capable of.
