Why the F$#@& does Yelp ask about Gender Neutral restrooms. If you do not know what you are, you should not go out in public.

I love this place. Definitely one of my favorite places to go. What can I say about it? Well, the staff is attentive and friendly and the place is always clean, even if its packed. The guys on the grill really add to the atmosphere and always put a smile on my face. The food itself is fresh and I always manage to make something delicious and fresh tasting. Love the relaxed atmosphere and always make an effort to go when I'm in the neighborhood. Might want to consider making a reservation on the weekends, otherwise you will have a bit of a wait.
pretty cool! kinda dirty, and overpriced a tad.. it was a one time thing. tasty -- but nothing special.

The first time we went was a Sunday afternoon and it was pleasant. Not too many people and no line to cook your food. Went for the second time this last weekend on a Saturday night and probably won't make that mistake again. Of course super good food! Thankfully we made reservations because the line was out the door. Also line for the food and then line to cook your food was significant. Need plenty of time and plenty of quarters for the meters if you go at prime time!

If you want original tasting asian food, this is definitely not the place to go. HOWEVER, if you want fresh tasting food, then give this place a try. You can mix and match your meat and vegetables and sauces.

A buffet comes with a endless salad bar as well. They are really busy at night. If you want authentic asian food, then maybe this is not where you want to go.

Overall, I would give it a 3.5 star.

Our server was extremely rude. She was slamming utensils and rolling her eyes constantly. 
No greetings and was not tentative. We felt like we were not welcome and were rushed.

The food is overpriced and we got egg shells in our meal.

It was so bad that I created this Yelp account to give this review.

Picture this:  2001, Cleveland Heights.  A suburban-Akron recent high school graduate finally discovers parts of Cleveland that aren't Fat Fish Blue, Peabody's, or a "Battle of the Bands" venue.  While touring JCU with some friends who were attending we stumbled upon Coventry and all the magic it holds.  It was then, my friends, that my love affair with BD's started.

My friends and I made weekly trips up to Coventry to check out the shops, grab some BD's, and explore the area.  This place has it all right: all-you-can-eat-make-your-own-stir-fry.  Chicken, read meats, fish, vegetables, tofu, sauces, spices, everything.  You can make a new recipe every time and never run out of options.  My personal favorite bowl consisted of chicken, baby corns, carrot sticks, pineapple, edamame, broccoli, pasta noodles, a ladle of bottom tickler and a ladle of peanut sauce to balance it all out.  Throw in some cajun seasoning and lemon pepper, wrap it in a flour tortilla with some brown rice, and you've got yourself some heaven in a bowl!  Also, they bang an annoying gong and bring you a free dessert if it was your birthday.  I can't tell you exactly how many "birthdays" I've had here ;)

We continued to stop in weekly until we all went our separate ways for college.  Down in Athens I could never find something quite on par with BD's.  However, every time I came back up to the Cleveland-area for break or to visit friends, you betcha we stopped in at BD's.  Trust that.

As all good things seem to come to an end, so did my time in NE Ohio.  After graduating college I moved away to Chicago and started anew.  Sure, we have Flat Top Grill here, but it isn't quite the same as BD's.  I've heard that there are BD's in two far NW and SW suburbs, but I haven't been able to make it out there.  Finally, on my random trip home this past weekend, I was able to reunite with BD's and get my Mongolian BBQ on.  A 5 year sabbatical was entirely too long.  Since they've added new items and sauces to the buffet, t took me a couple bowls to really get my groove back and make the perfect bowl.  After playing around with the different sauces and spices I was able to come up with some good eats.  Overall, -1 star for discontinuing the bottom tickler sauce.  It was the best.  Don't mess with the best.

It'll be nice to get back up here again over the holidays when a bunch of my friends from "the gang" are in town, too.  The place is delicious, budget-friendly, and can satisfy even the pickiest (or "health-conscious") of appeties.  Also, allergy-sensitive patrons ARE welcome - just let them know and they will cook your meal separately in the back.

Love this place so much! It is nice that I can mix up and create my meal how I want. The price isnt bad, and it is really worth it to spend the $2 or $3 to have unlimited bowls. I will usually make one to eat there and one to take home for the next day. 

Its fun to see how much you can fit into your bowl. Seriously, you can have all your veggies, whatever meats, and pick the yummy sauces. Its all the goodness of cooking at home without actually have to cut, chop, cook, or clean anything. I will take that any day! 

The chefs are super nice and funny, and all around it is always a good time.

So obviously this place is user-dependent. If you know how to cook a bit and choose your items and sauces well, you're sure to win. If you're unable to do so.... you'll lose. So I'll rate them on what they can control.

I've been here 4 times so far. Every time the meat is well stocked with about 5 varieties of land meat (chicken, pepper sirloin, sirloin, and lamb), a few seafood options like squid, fish, and shrimp, and a couple bonus items here and there. The veggie options are similarly ample and varied with peas, baby corn, green peppers, and tofu being frequent. They also carry raw eggs.

They cook fast, they cook well. I've thrown some weird requests at them like the time I made a 8-egg breakfast omelette with potatoes, bacon, and cheese from the salad bar. They still nailed it.

The cost is like $15 for unlimited food that you can custom flavor. That's pretty good!


Jason's rank order list of Pittsburgh Buffets (updated occasionally):
top tier
- Quaker Steak (Robinson) - buffet tuesdays
- The Library (Carson) - buffet tuesdays and sundays
- BD's Mongolian bbq

Middle tier
- Quaker Steak (Pleasant Hills) - buffet tuesdays

Low tier
-Sushi Kim (friday and saturday kbbq buffet)

How to eat at BD's:
1) Fill up your bowl with ingredients from the self-serve area, which includes meats, tofu, noodles, vegetables, eggs, etc
2) Choose your sauces and seasonings (lots of options)
3) Watch the cooks grill your food

I like BD's because you can potentially fill up your bowl with a ton of food and take home any leftovers. For the standard price ($14) you are limited to one bowl, and this is what I usually order (as a student you get a discount on Wednesdays that comes to $10). If you fill up your bowl enough you can stretch the leftovers to last several meals.

For a little more ($2 more I think) you can eat buffet-style although this means you cannot take home any leftovers.

All in all, BD's is worth checking out at least once.

Great place with lots of options. The cooks at the grill make it an experience. You have your choice of meat, veggies, and sauces. Wish they had more than two Bbq sauces but that just a small thing. They send a free meal coupon on your birthday if you sign up with your email.  It is in a great area just to hang out in. Bring change for the parking meter across the street and behind Marc's.

Once again, I turn up Mid-Afternoon - Once again the place is around 60% full - once again I am led to a "Crappy" table right by the Grill so everyone gets to stare at me eating while they wait for the cooks to make their meal - which BTW the Line of people  was 20 deep - with people waiting to get to the grill.

I didn't eat - but I did take a look round  before i walked - again - they have place 4 tops in prime places, and in a way they can quickly be pushed together for groups. Then just crammed in 2 tops in the remaining gaps. 

If its busy - I get it - beggars can't be choosers and I don't expect to be seated somewhere that means a bigger group has to wait. Yes I know I could say something, but why should I have to?

I think this is the only Mongolian Style Grill in Pittsburgh, they clearly have plenty of customers, but if you are dining either as a Single or a Couple and don't like making a fuss, then right now I cannot recommend it.

Bad service. Bad food. All bad. 
Walked in and were basically ignored. Food was poor quality. Not coming back.

One of the best restaurants in cleveland I've been to, and yes I'm from Cleveland wonderful customer service and about of body experience all around. Food is everything!!!!  - I got the unlimited bowl... drinks just ok

The service was excellent. The quality of food was mediocre and the price was bit too pricey.

Service: excellent.  I went with my BF and he wanted all you can eat. I just wanted 1 plate. My first plate, I was mistaken into trying to follow the recipe and make my own sauce. It was GROSS, so I asked the waiter for another plate so I can try again, this time with premade sauce, thinking now i guess i have to pay for the AYCE price. The second place with the premade sauce was good. To my surprise, my waiter only charge me for the 1 plate price since i didnt even touch the first plate.

Food was good. Not great. But, we all thought the prices were way too high for what you get. The salad bar and soup we good. But, the plates were so small. How was that going to be a meal??
And what do you consider this place that has Asian stir fry, quesadillas, beer cheese soup, and salad bar. 
Not worth another trip in our book.

The concept here is just...awesome.  I love build-your-own, all-you-can-eat, salad bar option available places SO much. I really do.  

The food - terrific. As a seafoodie, I couldn't be more content. Scallops and salmon and shrimpies, oh my!

The layout - not bad.  Not perfect, but a-ok.

The price - depends on how hungry you are. For dinner I think one bowl is something like $13 and bottomless bowls are $15.  I say, go bottomless or go home.  Skip the salad bar though. It's a little bit of a waste of space.  And this is coming from salad bar's number one fan in the world.  I will say that the orange cream/tomato soup is pretty stellar and a nice complement to pour over your grill creation.

The service - oy.  It's not AWFUL. The staff is always friendly, but they just don't seem that efficient.  The best service I've had here has been at the bar with the bartender.  I'll probably take that route in the future and it seems that the main wait staff just can't totally figure it all out.  

Pretentious alert - I've been to China to an honest-to-goodness Mongolian grill. The food is pretty dang similar so Pittsburgh has a real gem here.  Allow enough time for service on the slow side and you'll leave satisfied.  Also, join their e-club - the coupons are the BEST.

If you don't like hibachi then you're not going to want to eat here.  

I wasn't sure if I wanted to stay when I first entered, but I am glad that I did.  I didn't get the concept of the restaurant at first, and was CONFUSED.  The menu also confused me too, but our waitress was very patient and informative.  You get a bowl, go to a buffet style area, place any assortment of seafood, meats, veggies and then a sauce and spices. into your bowl.  Walk it over to a grill area and a cook wills grill it up.  There is also a soup and salad  bar.  

I am thrilled that this restaurant is located in the Southside works,  this gives me just another dinner option that is within my budget.  We had a bowl each pot stickers a coke and a beer for $34.00.  

In my bowl I got shrimp, steak, tuna, snap peas, bell peppers, baby corns, chopped garlic and  pork. I choose the Ginger-chili sauce to go with. 

The combinations are endless. B.D Mongolian Grill has at least 10 meat options, even more veggie options and like 15 sauces and various spices.

I am eager to get back here an try out even more combos.
One downside is that if you are not very food savvy you can put together food combos that don't taste very good, or are too hot since the food is not professionally seasoned.  Even though the menu warns what sauces are very spicy, it can get very confusing since there are so many options.  I made mine some what spicy by adding additional red pepper flakes. 

There are no formalities here, the cooks sing when they get a tip and the customer gets to hit a gong. The music is loud and the drinks are pricey and the restaurant has a college cafeteria feel, but I liked it.
Expensive, but definitely worth the experience! If you didn't enjoy your meal, it's your own fault. Everything looks fresh and full, and watching the guys cook is really entertaining.

I went here for lunch with friends and loved it! If you haven't been here and you love stir-fry, you need to go. There's so many options of meats, tofu, veggies, sauces and spices. The possibilities are endless. I will definitely be going back! Seriously, try it! :)

Be sure to join their birthday club so you get a nice coupon that week! My boyfriend and I went for my bday and it was an okay experience. The place has lots of toppings and meats even scallops which was nice to see! However the cooks burnt most of my plate which really put a damper on the whole experience.

Very cool place. The stir-fry is delicious and I love how we create our own, unique stir-fry's. Stir-fries? Anyway, it's very cool the way it's set up and I love watching the chefs prepare our food right in front of us. Also, I like they way they crack the egg.

I came here yesterday for the first time with a friend and my daughter.I have to say I was truely disappointed. 
When we arrived for lunch, the resturant was almost empty. The waitress we had was not in the mood for answering questions. I decided to go with the make your own but after getting up there, I wasn't sure what to make. I decided to order off the menu instead and got vegetable fried rice. My friend had done the buffet and was almost done eating by tbe time our rice cane. When I got it I could only taste salt. It came with an  undercooked, dripping egg on top. I also didn't find any veggies in my rice. My daughter was sharing the rice with me and did not like it either. My friend was also disappointed in his. He said the meat didn't taste right and all together it just wasn't good. I really love the concept, but the food was just bad.
I love this place. Took a friend there today and she was amazed. The gentlemen working on the grill made it go so far when the place was busy. Very entertaining.

The winning combination of D.I.Y. and dinner and a show, BD's is a totally glorious experience.
If you're doing a bowl (or multiple bowls), you're in complete control; personally selecting each perfect broccoli floret, each plump scallop, every drop of whatever sauce tickles your fancy. However much of whatever you desire, provided it fits in your bowl.
After this satisfying process, you present the fruits, vegetables, and meats of your labor to the grill cook... And the show begins.
Using utensils that are part tongs, part knife, they prepare your meal with the flair of a true maestro.
You end up with your very own personalized masterpiece. It's beautiful, and it's okay to cry tears of joy as you eat it.

Also worth noting: the cocktails are worth considering, the beer list is usually quite decent, and if you're adding soup and salad bar, keep your eyes peeled for the Creme Andaluz... It is savory and sooo creamy.

About a month ago I visited B&D's in Coventry. Having been to the location in Columbus, OH I already knew to expect awesome food, a good atmosphere, and to not leave hungry. 

It was Saturday night and it was PACKED! The host gave us an accurate time of how long we should expect to wait, and my party was totally okay with it. Once we were seated our waiter got us started with drinks and let us know how to get the best dish using the menu cards available which was very helpful. 

Although it took a by longer than I had hoped to get a refill as well as desert, the dinner was what I expected. The reason this experience is getting only two stars is because of what I spotted on my way out of the restroom. On the wall close to the grill, where everyone's food is being prepared, a COCKROACH! I immediately informed the staff and multiple of them just stood there staring at it. My stomach is turning again just thinking about it. 

I will return to B&D's, but NOT to this location.

Sanitary  issues. Potential cross-contamination issues by placing raw fish dishes  in vegetable  buffet area. Appeared no one was monitoring for proper buffet item placement or line cleanup. Quick and attentive service.  Some vegetable ingredients not fresh. Cooking grill not cleaned and our dishes contained burnt residue chips from grill. Parking issues with City garage and parking lots. Parking meters only accept payment for a maximum of one hour. Be prepared to make return trip to feed meters during busy times. City of Cleveland Heights quick to issue $15.00 parking violation. Also no change machines in garage. It is as if The City of Cleveland Heights is creating the environment  to enhance revenue from parking violations.

The buffet is an interesting mix of meats, veggies, rice noodles, several sauces, and seasonings. Take your selections up to the chefs and watch them cook your food on the spot. Hot and fresh. Seating is a little to close together.

Make your our Chinese food can be a hit or miss but one thing is sure that in the bowl given to you, the choicest of ingredients and proteins can be put. They do provide a recipe booklet if you want to play it safe or one can be the adventurous self. Hard to criticize the food when you make it. At the end of it the food coma is for sure. They have a menu as well. The salad and soup comes with entree. They have a kids menu. We took their anniversary desert which was mintalicious. Overall a good place worth revisiting if it was closer to home.

I wasn't overly excited about visiting this place simply because they are pretty common where I am from. My boyfriend had never been so it was a great experience for him. The food was good. A bit overpriced for what it is, but I guess that's where they need to be if they are in Southside? I don't remember it being quite as expensive back home.

Problem with this place? The music was so loud, that our server had to yell to talk to us. My boyfriend even noticed it. "Is she yelling?!?" She was so loud that when she would talk over the music to the table next to us, I would get annoyed. The staff was friendly and even found themselves singing along to the music as they cleaned. Which I was happy to see everyone in a good mood. But why were there so many!? They had their own show choir going on here on a Tuesday night. There were literally more people working than there were eating (I counted haha). And that's even including the 3 employees who I watched eating in the kitchen. I was just too overwhelmed with people working to feel comfortable. They were everywhere! Maybe it was to ensure the restaurant does well since it's new? Maybe the manager doesn't know how to cut workers after a certain point? Maybe I was an extra eating in the background for an episode of Glee?

First time trying with group of friends. The selections of fresh items to choose are limitless. You can pick fresh meats, seafoods numerous fresh vegetables and a fabulous choice of sauces. Then after you fill your bowl you take it over to the grill. The guys at the grill are all friendly and entertaining. The food is then grilled to perfection and finished with your sauce choice. The cost for one bowl or unlimited bowls was only $3. And with either choice is the unlimited soup and salad bar. The table service was not all the great but since you select your own food and the grill guys cook it that can be overlooked. So if you want fresh foods cooked in front of you that is healthy and delicious, then eat here. 
Just remember to hit the gong and tip the grill guys well, they really deserve it!!!

Typical Mongolian grill. Prices are OK. I've only been once, but the service wasn't the greatest. I'll be sure to update my review next time I go, as I definitely plan to try it out again.

What stands out, for me, was the wide selection meats, veggies, and especially the tasty sauces and spices. One can really go nuts with the options.

Protip, from watching others - get the most out of your bowl by loading the meats and veggies FIRST, then pile a "birds nest" of noodles on top. People were really impressive with how high their bowls were stacked with noodles.
I've been here a few times and it's always great. The food is delicious and the employees always  seem happy! I would highly recommend for any occasion.

My husband was excited to find out we now live near a BD's, so we made a visit there last weekend. It was crowded on a Saturday night, but with an OpenTable reservation we were seated right away.

If you're familiar with Mongolian grills, you know the set-up-- fill your bowls with meat and veggies, pick your sauce, and then they grill it up for you. I like that they have separate bowls for adding sauce later in the cooking process, since it helps prevent sogginess. Their meat quality is decent; I liked the pork, and my husband likes that they have multiple steak options. They have quite a few good beer options, and a nice drink menu too. You can make multiple trips to the grill or just one (if you do one you can keep your leftovers).  Your grill entree comes with your choice of white or brown rice, as well as lettuce wraps and oddly, tortillas.  They have a salad bar and an array of appetizers too, but save your money and your calories and stick to the grill. Our server was too busy, but quite friendly.

If you're new to town or unfamiliar with the area, street park's limited, but there's plenty of meters in the lot down the street.  It's a little bit on the expensive side, but it's a fun experience sometimes so I'd happily make a repeat visit.

This is a nice stop in the South Side.  Meals are a good value.  Lots of fresh vegetables and tasty sauces.  The staff is friendly.     I enjoy having the opportunity to mix items in a big bowl so that every meal can be different.   Choice of spices allow you to satisfy your mood of the day.  This is worth a try.  I'll be back.

get the all you can eat--it was great.


Ask for Julia to be your server---she is so sexy.

the food is pretty good.  you get out of it what you combine, and i think that the open grill is actually pretty cool.

this place gets two stars because their customer service is pretty bad.  one time i went, i was basically told they couldn't serve me because it was an hour before close.  the last time i went with my girlfriend, we sat at the bar (because the greeter tried to put us in a corner and i wasn't keen for that) and the bartender looked at me as if we weren't supposed to eat there.

does the environment produce bad customer service?  i mean, it's not like mcdonald's or burger king...but i just expected a little bit more welcoming behavior and not feeling like im rushed.
This place is pretty good. And coming from a picky sometimes eater, getting to choose exactly what meat, veggies etc I want is always a plus!

The first thing you notice when you walk in is the dirty, dingy smell. Floors are sticky. There's some type of black gooey stuff on the floor in the women's bathroom. Chairs and tables have random wet spots. It's basically a cafeteria with a bar in it and I can see how it's really popular with college kids because they just don't know any better. It reminds me of trying to eat something at an amusement park. I half expected to see kids running around in bathing suits. I think if you don't know how to cook anything on your own this is really fascinating because you get to watch your food cook. The bowl they give you is tiny and that's the portion you get for $15. It's over priced, sticky, gross and a nightmare for people with food allergies. How long has this place even been here? How did it make it this far?

I see mixed reviews. Your meal will only be as good as what you choose to put in. It will be an advantage to have some cooking experience. There's a few caveats, the smoky environment will have you smelling like the place after you leave. The iron "shield" where they cook the food is infused with so many spices that there will no need to season your dish with the powder spices provided, if anything, your food will taste spicy even without it, much like how a cast-iron skillet retains all the flavors in it's lifespan.

I cook at home and love stir fry. They win with a few things right: by having everything cooked on a very hot surface, everything gets a nice sear without drying, much like what you get when you cook on a very hot wok. Everything is chopped into small pieces too, so the cooking is even. 

Here's what I usually mix: despite the instructions advising against it, I mix seafood especially shrimp and scallops with beef (have they ever heard of surf and turf?). I usually add onion, bean sprouts, mushroom and bok-choi. I choose the black bean but mix it with peanut sauce (again despite clear instructions to choose only one sauce). I've come up with good stuff here.

You're on Coventry. What are you doing at a chain of Mongolian restaurants? OK, I get it, sometimes you have a craving for this type of food and Mongolian BBQ is a place to get it. 

If you do eat here, go before 4pm. Once they switch over to the dinner menu (which is the same as the lunch menu at higher prices) it becomes a very poor value.

Stir fry is one of those things that most people can make decently at home, but you need so many ingredients that it becomes a pain. Mongolian BBQ lets you custom build your bowl down to the specific selection of sauces and spices. For this I give Mongolian BBQ credit.

This is by no means at the top of my list of places to eat in Cleveland Heights, but I'll go there if someone else really wants to. It's not a place to be avoided, but it's not a place to be sought out.

I gave this place a second chance... But I have to say, I won't be coming back. I like the idea that you get to build your own stir-fry and watch it get made, kinda like a communal hibachi but...

- restaurant was lacking in ambience
- the selection of food to pick from wasn't that great - the seafood didn't look fresh...
- the food was seriously bland regardless of how much hot sauce was dumped in it.
- customer service was lacking.

Inedible. I think the grill guy forgot my order. It was on the grill for over 15 minutes. Standing there for so long was bad enough. The beef turned to rubber bands. The rice noodles had turned into a hardened mass that would require a chainsaw to cut. Bartender was nice.

Really struggled to talk myself into eating here.  I imagined some scene from the 1965 film "Gengis Khan" and some old and equally intimidating beef with heavy sauces and just too much seasoning.  I was cold, so I decided to try it out anyway.  

Let me tell you, I am THRILLED I did!  I ordered the Pad Thai with Shrimp and it was delicious!  It was light, flavorful and delivered quickly with a smile.  Looking forward to trying some of their other dishes, because I'm intrigued.  The waitress told me about a steak and mushroom soup, which I promised myself I'd try next time I came by.

Wasn't busy for lunch, sat down, ate and was back out the door in less than 25 minutes! A+
The taste of the meal largely depends on your choice of the sauce. Great place to eat when you are hungry.

Four stars because the food was tasty. 

So here's MY issue with the place, though I'm sure many wouldn't consider this an issue.. There are so many options. I'm terrible at making decisions so my head was spinning as I was in line picking my ingredients. 

Basically you select from a buffet of raw meat and vegetables, sauces and seasonings. You put as much of these ingredients as you want / can fit in the bowl they give you. Next you wait in line to have them cook your food in front of you on a big round grill. From start to finish this process could take 20 minutes.. Maybe a little less or longer depending on how busy it is. 

For about $15 you get one bowl, $18 you get unlimited. But I warn you, if you fill your bowl right one bowl is PLENTY. The unlimited option is a good way to try different combinations but with waiting in line to pick your food then waiting to have it cooked you're looking at a lengthy lunch or dinner. 

The food is very reminiscent of hibachi...except you have to select your ingredients, stand to wait for your food to be cooked and get no Chinese volcanoes or broccoli thrown at your face.

Good food but definitely just a once or twice a year spot.

After a movie we decided to try this place. We both got the unlimited trips with the salad bar. The waitress was helpful explaining how it worked. Great choices. First trip I got a mix of meats, vegggies, and teriyaki sauce. Everything was good very well, great flavor. Second round was seafood, shrimp & calamari, veggies,& a mix of teriyaki and ginger sesame sauce. And the last trip was shrimp and ribeye with veggies and ginger sesame. 2 of the 3 grill guys were fun, 1 was grumpy.  Tipped the cooks on my last trip, please tip. Salad bar was small but fresh.  Definitely want to go back. Great place.

I took my grandma and my sister here on one glorious day after visiting the Columbus location, and I can say that we were not disappointed.

Every customer receives a bowl and fills it as high as he or she can, then watches as the cooks cook the contents of their bowl on a stone grill.  The cook even performs a juggling show with his cooking knives (or whatever they are).

I found the variety of meats and veggies to be jaw-dropping. But that wasn't even the most impressive part. There were far too many sauces and rubs to try at once. The restaurant even provides a list of sauce combinations that could be used to "enhance" the flavor of the meats and veggies as they are being cooked.

I do not like Chinese food - the Mongolian BBQ is a bit of a misnomer, as this is neither BBQ nor of Mongolian origin - but this was my favorite meal this past month.

Had the taco's on taco Tuesday . Fish and chicken were good. Didn't care for the pork. For 6.99 you can't beat it. I will say their rice dishes are dry and have too much sodium but overall still a good deal. Staff was friendly.

Stars: 2+

Pros: If you are hungry and just want pure quantity over quality, this can fit the bill. The variety its probably Mongolian BBQ's best asset. They also provide soft tacos and white rice. The sauces are OK, to be honest, everything else was below par.

The cooks are very nice and always strike up conversations. 

Cons: The seafood does not taste very fresh, but hey its a buffet. That's to be expected...i think?......... The meat, is alright.  

If you are in a group, chances are that someone is always up getting food and waiting for the food to be cooked (which does take a while). Not a good place to relax and chat over dinner.

I like this place for the most part. AYCE only cost an extra $2 compared to a single bowl. One bowl isn't quite large enough to fill me up, so it's almost mandatory to go for the unlimited option. These types of restaurants are cool, but can be too flexible when trying to put together a good combination. The sauces can really make or break a dish and without knowing what they taste like can really be like taking a shot in the dark. Luckily, if you strike out and you do AYCE, you can simply try again, but each trip can take about 10-20 min depending if there is a line or not. I'd suggest thinking of a popular stir fry dish that you like and sticking to what you know before venturing off the beaten path. Lastly, a plus is they will let you box up your last plate if you can't finish it, which some places won't let you do.

Where do I start. The restaurant was filthy...sat us at a sticky table. We were moved to a better table but the place can use a good cleaning.  The waiter was either overwhelmed or needs additional training.  He was slow and forgetful. We had to wait for bowls, rice, tortillas...everything. The food and price was good for all you can eat stir fry. We would only consider or recommend if you needed a cheap kid friendly option.

I ordered one bowl and stuffed it with many ingredients and strong sauce. The sauce was mixed with Shanghai BBQ, Chili Garlic, Kung Pao, Soy Sauce, Garlic, Chopped Peanuts, Rosemary, Mixed Herbs, Sesame Seeds. This is my Khan's Recipe. With such a strong taste, I swallowed two bowls of white rice.

Went there with a family group of 12. We had small children and adutls allergic to seafood. Our waitress was wonderful- she kept bringing drink refills, napkins and more bowls.  The set up was great and the  place was clean. I also think the prices were reasonable..  about 15.00 pp for unlimited trips.

 I do agree that it was slightly cafeteria style and many times the people working the grill would yell to  "stand here"  after  we had already stood next to family  or friends and places our food down. One  other slightly confusing thing was the add of the  salad bar..didn't really understand if  it was  included or you paid extra.

Over all a decent place to eat.

I'm such a huge fan of bd's! I was very sad when the one in Irvine closed & one of the best things I learned about Pittsburgh when I moved back was that there was a bd's here! It's just as good as my old local restaurant. I wish it were a bit closer. The food is amazing and you get to pick what they make for you from fresh ingredients. If you haven't been there yet, go soon!!

Place was filthy everywhere (floor, tables, counters, etc...) we looked.  Food bins were messy, low, empty and cross contaminated.  No chance we will ever go back.  Maybe hire a manager that knows how to run a resturant.

We love this place! I only dock a point because the salad bar is plentiful but weak in quality. But, it is *only* the salad bar- the real quality is in the stir fry. Mix together your own bowl of meat, veggies, and sauces- then watch them splash it on a hot grill and cook it to your liking. You get to control your own quantities within each bowl, so it doesn't end up mostly veggies like most Chinese delivery places. You can go one bowl or unlimited. For unlimited it is absolutely worth the price. Both options include the salad bar, which has soup, salad, and fruit.

Ate lunch here with my son and a small group of hockey players/parents after a tournament game in Cleveland Heights about a week ago. This was my first experience at a BD's Mongolian BBQ and it was quite different. I wasn't really a big fan of having to walk through a buffet line to pick out my own meats and veggies (using a very small bowl, mind you) and then take them to a grilling station to be prepared on my behalf while I waited. It's definitely an interesting concept - and worth giving a try - and the food was alright. But for my tastes, the effort wasn't worth the payoff.

I'd never been to Mongolian BBQ on Coventry, so went to lunch with the family, including two little kids.  We were a midday, midweek walk-in, but I understand that at times there can be a rather long wait so it's best to call ahead for reservations.

This is a casual restaurant so there is no need to feel like you must dress up.  That place has a very laid back atmosphere.   The place well lit, multileveled and the focal point is the grill area.  

Mongolian BBQ is a buffet, yet not your traditional buffet.  After being seated and explained (for me) the concept and how the restaurant works, you place an order for a type of rice or tortilla/wrap, then are shows to the buffet area.  The choices consist of wide array of meats, vegetables, sauces and spices. This allows you to create the meal you want.  After you select your ingredients, you head the grill area and the "chefs" prepare you meal right in front of you.  Once you get back to your table, your server will have brought your rice to the table.

I had no opinion of the quality of the items eaten, as they were stocking the buffet on occasion, the area appeared clean, well kept and at the appropriate room temperature. 

Overall a good place for a quick lunch or family meal.  I would also say this is not a date place, but more a place to meet friends before starting the evening.

As much as I was thinking this place was going to be awful, I was very surprised that we enjoyed our experience.

The items in the buffet seemed quite fresh and kept up, which was a huge plus as a lot of places like this can indeed be a tad more iffy.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  The lunch was really cheap.  I will say that my husband was not a fan of the Crab Rangoon, so if that is something that you typically love, you may want to avoid it here.  

Will I go back?  Maybe.  It is so close to home, it makes it convenient when we are not up for everything else that this side of Carson St has to offer.

I love so-called Mongolian BBQ but haven't had it in years. During the 1998 Olympics in Nagano, someone setup a Mongolian BBQ restaurant for the month and I think we ate there every night.

To be clear, the Mongolian BBQ concept we know isn't really authentic to Mongolia. It's a pretty Westernized concept. That being said, it's still good. 

In a weeklong trip to my old hometown of Madison, we checked out the bd's Mongolian Grill at East Towne. It's a franchise location with restaurants in 11 states, according to its Web site. We had a group of five - all Mongolian BBQ virgins - including a six year old. It was a big hit.

The thing that stood out above everything was the high level of customer service and training level of the staff - from the host to waiter to cooks. It was a great team environment with lots of energy. If you're new to the process of stacking food in a bowl and having someone else cook it, it can be daunting. The staff does a good job of working you through the system.

Dinner was pretty good value - about $12 for a bowl with rice, a buck more for a salad. And you can go unlimited for another buck. I think our son threw a pound of New York strip into his bowl. I stacked mine with prime rib, shrimp and scallops. It was quick, fun, and healthier than our stop at nearby Old Country Buffet two nights earlier.

Even the six year old had fun watching the process and learning how to use her kids chopsticks.

This is a really good franchise operation! We'll be back on another trip.

We just ate here with our family and the food was ok. But the table was sticky and when we got up to leave my husband heard a squeak under the table when he went to get up and there was a mouse chillin under our table now I'm sitting on the toilet with explosive diarrhea!!!!

I work in the service industry and have for a long time and look at certain things and listen for certain things when I enter a restaurant. That being said, I am really satisfied with the level of service I was met with. I was approached by my server Mike and gave my friend who had never been here a thorough break down of who you are and how it works. He was friendly, met all our needs in an immediate and courteous way and was relatable. The cooks didn't look like they hated their lives and worked charismatically with mild flare and was a joy to watch. I could tell the one was new but was focused and put the final touches on my entree with success. I believe his name was (Kyle) good job. The salad bar was cleanly and neat, the ingredients were fresh, the lettuce was not wilted or brown, and they had a decent amount of options. Hell yes to whatever that "Crema Andaluz" soup is... So good. I also listen to hear excessive boh/foh profanity and I refreshingly couldn't hear any NSFW conversations or servers talking negatively about their tables. (That's really nice and shows people seemingly like working here) 

I feel like establishments like this, that are partially self serviced, get overlooked and underrated. We will be back. (As it is now one of my friend's new favorites) All he kept saying to himself as he was piling food in his mouth is "This is so good. This is so f%*king good."

Make sure you give Mike some credit. He's great at his job and not many servers are. 

Keep it up.

I really love Mongolian grills, but this place was lousy. The white rice was undercooked and crunchy and the brown rice was overcooked and mushy. It was also super salty and inedible. The stuff we fried up was mediocre. We left our food and didn't take it with us.

Overall, I enjoyed it here.  It's essentially a create/build your own stir-fry.  The waitress brings you a bowl and then you can go to town at the buffet style setup of ingredients.  Once you've chosen your meats, veggies and sauce, you go up to the grill and they grill your concoction while you watch.

For my first bowl, I went with chicken, pasta, broccoli, peppers, carrots, egg and a chili garlic sauce (one of the hottest sauces on the menu).  For my second bowl, I went with scallops, rice noodles, carrots, water chestnuts, bean sprouts, egg, broccoli and the teriyaki sauce.  I really like a lot of flavor in my meal and love anything spicy so my preference was the first but they were both good.  They also will bring out rice, shells or lettuce wraps if you want to use those with your bowl of goodies.  

Here's what I didn't like...the strawberry peach sangria.  I love a sweet drink more than the average person but after waiting for about 20 minutes, I was really disappointed with our pitcher of sangria. Where was the wine portion of this drink?  It tasted like kool-aid mixed with Sprite.  BOMB.  I hardly ever leave a drink behind but I did here.  The rest of the table was equally disappointed.  

We also opted for a brownie sundae to share for dessert.  It was gigantic and it was good but didn't blow me out of the water.  I don't know why.  Maybe because I wanted the brownie to be warm and melt in my mouth and it didn't. 

Lastly, I'll say that we went here for the soft opening so it was very crowded, the waiters/waitresses were brand new and didn't know the menu very well and the service (including the bar) were running behind.  My only warning is to fill your first bowl as high as you can.  Once it cooks down, it doesn't seem like much is there.  One bowl left me feeling hungry and wanting more but two made be feel as though I had gorged myself silly and shouldn't have gone up for more.

We stopped here to celebrate my birthday a day late. We literally live a block away but just havent stopped by here.

I piled my bowl high with noodles, chicken, onions, broccoli, mushrooms, corn, peanuts, egg.. most likely some other things that i'm forgetting. yum it was good. I loooove how at the end they have spices because i season my chicken really well when cooking. They had fresh garlic and garlic powder, crushed red pepper and other things that i  cant remember at the moment. I also like the sign that helps you with the sauce (add 2 ladles of this, one of that, this season to make it taste asian) They did that for recommendations of asian, italian, mexican and some other ideas. TIP: keep your chicken on the side to add seasons directly to it. 

For dessert, we decided on the brownie sundae--- delicious!! I just may head over one day when only craving a brownie sundae.. They also had fried oreos (4) served with ice cream as well as some other tasty desserts.

We just missed happy hour, but i still asked our server for the HH details for future reference. They have great deals on drinks and appetizers. They also have deals on beer the day of a pens game. Speaking of drinks.. this place made a GREAT drink. We only ordered a crown & coke, but it was STRONG!! do you know how many times i've had a weak drink at a chain restaurant? Enough that I stopped buying drinks when out to dinner. I just head to a bar afterwards if i want a drink lol.. 

The workers on the grill were very nice and friendly, as well as our server. I'm excited to head back during warmer hours to enjoy the outdoor seating. Oh, this place plays an interesting mix of music.. I heard everything from the newest songs on pop radio to Hanson's "mmm bop" & Come on ride the train (hehehe)

I just tried this once to see how it was and seriously feel no need to go back. $8.99 for lunch and $13.49 for dinner which you will never see posted on their webpage. The novelty of the whole place is what must bring people in the door. There was a place in Squirrel Hill a few years back that let you pick your meat and vegetables for a stir fry and they had since closed up and became the Silk Elephant. 
I couldn't really see a point in tipping a waitress when the setting is very informal and you are basicly doing all the work. They bring you an empty bowl when you sit down and then your rice and drink if you choose to order one. In my opinion if everything were like Chipotle where you get your own drink and no need to tip someone all the better. I guess I am just a cheapskate but when you are eating this kind of food you really don't want to spend that much cash as a whole. If we had a Pei Wei here in Pittsubrgh then there really would not be much need for a place like BD's. I noticed the onions were cut up all half assed where they leave the core at the end in there and don't care that it is all clumped up and stuck together. One of my pet peeves. 

Not sure what the draw is here getting your food cooked on a dirty grill by a teenager who would rather shoot the breeze than check to see if your food is burning. Watching him turn and chop my food (loosing a few select pieces of meat into the spill well during the process) with what looked like two filthy sword like utensils was not very appetizing at all. I think when someone else came up behind me and he scraped the grill shooting black carcinogenic ash into my stirfry was the final straw that made me not want to go back. I chose a mixture of about 5 different sauces that completely dried up once poured over my food on the grill. I couldn't really tell what it tasted like since it was so dried out and full of black specs of charcoal.

If you want something similar and willing to pay the asking price of $9 for lunch, just go to a good Hibachi Grill somewhere where you get a free entertaining show by a real chef. If that's not for you either I suggest one of the better Chinese buffets around town and pay $7 instead and get all you can eat along with salad, fruit, cookies and ice cream.

This is a great little spot for lunch or dinner. One of my favorite places to go for a fun meal. 

The build your own dish is what makes this one shine for me. I think it;s a blast to go in and be able to pick all the parts or my meal, then see them cooked with some flair on a giant grill. I can always find unique combinations and flavors, and no meal is ever the same. Even better if you have a buddy or two to compare creations!  

The ingredient choices are pretty widely varied, and always fresh. Plenty of meat or veggies for anyone's taste. Spices and sauces galore. 

Service is a plus here as well, every time I've been, the staff is super friendly, and they always seem to be having a good time.

amazing happy hour, especially during Mondays it runs 5-9. Half off wines drafts and appetizers and 2$ off specialty drinks making the margarita only 3$!!!! There's so many flavors to choose from too! Blood orange, prickly pear, Mai tai.. Too many to name! Great place to start to explore south side !

I've been coming here since I was a child and it's still as good as I remember from my childhood. The staff is always really friendly and the grillers get your food cooked fast! 

We went this most recent time on a Friday evening around 6 and honestly that was the perfect time because about 45 minutes later is when the crowd started to file in. You can create your own flavor combinations or use the recipe cards they have at the beginning of the meat bar. Whatever you do you definitely want to pile on the meat and veggies even though it looks like a lot in your bowl, it cooks down to significantly less. You also want to make sure you  get the rice and tortillas, it really brings the whole meal together. 

The only thing I wish was different about this place is the fact that they keep the sauces and spices near the grill. Basic finishing sauces like sriracha, hot sauce and soy sauce should be available at every table so you don't have to keep getting up to flavor your food. I also wish I would have asked for my egg just fried and on top, they scramble it in so make sure you make that clear if that's your thing. 

Overall great experience and I obviously will continue to eat here because the food is so good and it's always an effortless and fun experience.

I love a place that I get to be as picky and annoying with my food choices as possible without annoying any one of the staff. First, you pick all your own things. I LOVE this. Second, you watch them cook it up and it's quite cool to watch. 

My rookie mistake was I didn't realize to put the sauce choice on the side and I can ensure you if you select the marinated meat, you don't need a sauce... it was too salty but that was a user error. 

The good thing is for a few bucks more you can do unlisted times so if you make the mistake such as I did you can get something else! Yum.

Been driving by this place for year, but never felt the urge to stop, since the menu is not in my usual zone.  Stopped by to meet some friends who love this place.  Decor is busy, clean, fast-food like.  Servers were friendly and attentive.  The basic concept is make your own stir fry and they will cook it for you and add some rice.  Overall, seems nice, just not my personal favorite.  If you like stir fry, good place to go.

I actually quite like this concept. It is essentially a AYCE buffet (I would assume most people go for the unlimited bowls, unless they're skilled at filling a single bowl to the brim), where the only type of food you can get is stir fry. But they have a huge number of ingredients, probably more than enough to satisfy whatever craving you have. I like the fact that I can choose exactly how much meat and veggies I'm feeling, along with the sauce choice. The meat looks mostly fresh and fine and prepared well, and the veggies all look presentable. Even the sauces have a lot of variety, and I appreciate that I can get a stir-fry that is not overly salty. Finally, while we did not try any of their appetizers or desserts, the soup and salad bar were pretty sufficient for finishing (yay watermelon!).

Pro-tip: Their prices, both lunch and dinner, are very comparable to Hokkaido, and the food turned out tasting much better.

Went here for dinner...waitress didn't explain how it worked very well and then gave my date a hard time about only having a drink and not ordering any food. Since they have a full bar area, I'm not sure why it would be weird to just come in for a drink...the food was good, but I can't get over how bad the service was! Not sure when/if I'll go back

This place is great! You can customize your meal every time. Here is a tip we learned from a regular: put your veggies on the bottom FIRST! Then the meats will weigh everything down. You can fit more in ur bowl!! Don't forget to tip and bang the gong!

I know it is a chain, but it probably is our favorite.The grilling style is really cool to watch. Not to fancy, but we'll worth the trip.    We had reservations for 6 on Mother's Day and were seated right away. That wait staff at this location has always been very friendly and knowledgeable about their selections and this day was no exception. The food was fresh and the food bar was well maintained and clean.
   There is always plenty to choose from and we have never been disappointed with the quality. If you are looking for a different experience and want really good food I would highly recommend BD's Mongolian.

I have to admit I was skeptical about this place before going there last weekend for the first time. What is Mongolian food?? Will they have anything I can eat there? Isn't this a chain? I don't like chain restaurants. Then I stopped whining and looked online at the menu. I was intrigued and agreed to go.
I'm actually glad I did. The dining room was not exciting, very basic. We took our seats and our waitress asked if we had been here before. My wife has been to one in Maryland, but I answered "no", expecting an explanation of what I was supposed to do. Well, she plopped a bowl down in front of me and walked away. Umm, ok. My wife thankfully was able to walk me through the process.
There were many starches to start making your own stir fry with. Rice noodles, egg noodles, pasta, you can ask your waitress for rice and tortillas. Great. Next we made our way to the veggies, walking past heaps of very unappealing raw meats. I don't eat meat, but people seemed to like it. I just hope it was in some sort of refrigerated container. I loaded my bowl with some tofu, and was impressed with the selection of vegetables being presented in this salad bar type procession. Edamame, bean sprouts, and bamboo were among the more typical beans, potatoes, baby corns and water chestnuts. I piled my bowl high and went for the sauces. They had tons to choose from, you could essentially make your own by combining a few. I tried the lemon initially. Then we walked over to the "grill".
This thing is massive. They can cook LOTS of food at once, and I have no idea how they keep it all straight. They asked me if I had any food allergies, and I told them I was a vegetarian. They promptly cleaned and scrubbed the grill, then sectioned it off before placing my creation down, which I liked. The possibility of meat juices contaminating my dinner isn't pleasant. The guys at the grill were very skilled, not to mention entertaining to watch. They added the sauce to my wonderfully cooked stir fry, and I took it to my seat.
I was surprised how tasty it was. The tofu was even nicely browned, and the provided chopsticks - bonus. We decided to try another round (they have an all you can eat type option), and picked at our second bowls worth, as we were already quite full. 
Our waitress was not attentive. When she handed us our second bowls, she disappeared. I think we waited 30 minutes from the time we finished eating until she came to ask us if we needed anything. She never asked how anything was, and our waters were gone. I would have given this place 3.5-4 stars if we had better wait staff service. Seriously, it's not like she even had to bring us our food! The guy at the table behind us had a bowl of raw meat sitting on his table for 10 minutes before one of the hostesses told him what he was supposed to do. She never told him either.
I will probably come back, as I enjoyed the choices and the flavors. I just hope I get a different waitress.

Great first experience! Cooks were knowledgeable and food was fabulous. Only complaint really was the server seemed to be annoyed and curt when I said I'd never been there before and said since my friend had that he could show me around and how to do everything. Other than that I really loved it!
I really like it recommend this place.I also like the way it works to make the stir fry and the people who work there are very nice...Shoutout to Snoop.

I came to this place because a family friend was in town and enjoyed it wanted to go back for a second time in the same week. It seems like a cool concept, but I did not like certain things. I think while it is a fun idea to "make your own dish" it didn't make for a nice dinner. It made it feel fast food-ish. Not somewhere I'd want to go on a date. The whole getting food process wasn't as fun as it should've been either lots of waiting so conversation time was definitely lost. If you know how to make Mongolian I'd say go ahead try it if not, go somewhere the prepare the dishes for you.

Love love love love love this place. Don't know how many times I've been here now, was trying to do lunch once a week or every other week. Can't beat the quality for the price. Delicious soups that aren't the same old stuff you get at other places. The bacon on the salad bar is best I've had on a salad bar. I go early for lunch, beat the crowd and no waiting.

Friends of ours hosted a New Year's Eve Eve party, complete with a limo bus and cocktails, video scavenger hunt at the mall (yes, we're all grown adults), and dinner at BD's Mongolian BBQ.  

Hubby and I have had this style of food before, but never like this.  I was impressed by the size of the place, and liked going down a set of stairs to get there.  It felt like we were stepping in to something special and exclusive.  I loved the vibe here.  It has a fun energy, as well as a variety of proteins, veggies, and seasoning choices to please any palate.  The lettuce for wraps was a nice touch.

Anthony was our server and did an incredible job of keeping our party of 13 happy.  He kept our drinks filled, explained the ordering system, kept the clean bowls coming, and smiled the entire time.  He even brought me a brownie sundae in honor of my birthday!

Life is good at BD's Mongolian BBQ.
Good choices, great variety. Love Mongolian BBQ. This place has a chain restaurant feeling, but they do a great job!   Recommended, especially during lunch time when the price is lower!

This Mongo Chain is just like the rest - decently fresh food prepared HOWEVER you want it, with a huge variety of interesting sauces, cooked by trained chefs that prepare your concoction quickly as possible.  

The catch is this one is crowded usually, which is fine if you don't mind a slight wait.  Plus there's a young crowd in there all the time cuz its on Coventry, so yes it might be louder than youre used to be its not that bad.  The view to the sidewalk above is pretty cool, and overall the staff is usually very friendly and doenst mind larger crowds.  

The price is the only reason for 4 stars - so go hungry if you plan to buy the dinner (instead of lunch) option.

I can't say anything about the quality of their food. I only sat at the bar long enough to enjoy a couple of beers and watch some March Madness. 

The quickest way to turn me off from returning to a restaurant is to let me whiteness the person who is serving me stuff food into their own face. While I understand that it was a slow night hardly want to see my bar tender stand behind the bar and consume a protein or weight loss shake. Next quickest way to not have me return: not washing your hands after touching dirty money and then touching plates with food on them.

Very disappointed as really used to enjoy this place. Went here for lunch on a Sunday, and had always enjoyed the lunch specials in the past, and this included weekends. 

When we sat down, we were handed dinner menus and told they don't do lunch on weekends. I had checked the website to make sure they still ran the specials, and they clearly had it listed with no date restrictions. 

Got up and left. Really unfortunate that they advertise one thing then change it when you get there. Also, one bowl for 14.99 for dinner is a TOTAL rip off.

Must remember dollars for tips! Very fun concept restaurant. always put your garlic on your protein, unless you're trying to ward off vampires and any breathing being. Ridiculous deals available, sign up for their emails, they have BOGO for your birthday. The meals alone are crazy, especially if they keep up the unlimited bowl option with to go. unheard of. Suppose that 's how you have to do it to keep such a large supply of fresh ingredients at the ready. Definitely loud. Check website to see if it's college night/ happy hour/ etc. Not the place for a quiet conversation. . . most days. . . maybe for lunch. . . defintiely as healthy as you want it to be, flavorful as well. you're at the helm of this ship, they do all the prep, cooking, cleaning, aaahhhh

OH Mongolian Barbeque how have I missed you!

So my friend and I was headed to a concert at the grog shop and decided to meet here for dinner.  This used to be my spot when I was younger!!!  I used to go here every year for my birthday, because you get this HUGE desert!  I believe they still do this!

So this is like a buffet/create your on dish type of restaurant.  For the price between $15-$18 you get to create a dish and all you can eat soup and salad bar.  Which I feel like it was a decent price.

They have all of the yummy goodness that you will need to create a great meal.  They have a variety of meat, tofu, veggies, sauces, pastas, and even spices!  And you can get a both rice and a tortilla to eat with your meal.  Trust AND believe this is a place that you can go to and get stuffed at.

Not only do they have their buffet bars, but you have an option to order appetizers and desserts.

What I truly appreciate about this place is that they separate your food if you tell them that you are a vegetarian or have any food allergies, which I appreciate.  Also!  It is very entertaining to watch the chefs do their thang on the grill.  Oh!  Before I forget, they have that special pop machine where you can get like a peach sprite and so on!  These are my favorites!

The reason why I am giving them a four (since you know I have LOVED this place since I was a teenie bopper) is that our waitress seemed busy or preoccupied.  I felt like she would come over to the table at the wrong times and when I did need her, I had to wait a while to get her attention.  Outside of that, my belly was happy at the end of the night!
Fun concept and thousands of combinations possible.  They even have cheesecake factory cheesecake for desert.

This is my #1 favorite restaurant in NE Ohio.  Has been since I was first introduced to it by my now parents-in-laws.  I think it's part of the reason I married my wife...

So, where to start - It isn't cheap and there is usually a wait for a table.  
Now that we've got that out of the way let's go over the food.

There's about a dozen different meats & seafood.  About fifteen different vegetables. Fifteen or so different sauces. And about a dozen different spices.   I'm not a super-genius mathematician but that's a whole lot of combinations.  The meats are good and the vegetables are fresh.  I'm allergic to shellfish so I can't tell you about it other than it's enjoyed by all the people I go with.  There's also a soup and salad bar.

Don't like your stir-fry creation? No problem!.. For a few bucks more it's all-you-can-eat.  After only a few visits to BD's I was able to master recreating my favorite bowl.

What's your signature bowl?

How many time have you been unhappy with your meal and secretly or not so much, told yourself: "Damn, I could have made this so much better!"  Well here at Mongolian they give you a chance to express yourself ... and turns out that really few of us are the Mongolians who can grill. As I was piling a bunch of raw goodness on my plate ( chicken, shrimp, sirloin), I was pretty sure that no way it can turn out bad.  I was really unfamiliar with sauces but having watched a couple of people pour something orange onto their plates, I decided: they must know what they are doing, and did the same. 
And then there was dramatic frying of the food on this huge round griller with some exhilarating which I found quite entertaining. 
When they handed me my meal, it looked nothing like I imagined. It looked ( and tasted) like a pile of over-fried garbage. Have you ever put all the jewelry you own at once? Good for you if you didn't. I have. And I experienced the same feeling eating the meal: it was too much at once. I felt incredibly guilty to throw it out so finished it as a punishment for my frivolous ways with fish, poultry and red meat at once.
Of course I acknowledge that "your second" plate is supposed to be oh so much better. But what to do with the first one? 
My husband actually loved it and ate it with Joey Tribiani's approach: What's not to like? Custard, good. Jam, good!  Meat, good!
I just wish someone could instruct me on how to make it all work. 
Also I am secretly grateful that some things are done by those who know how to do them; I prefer being creative in the areas which will not potentially jeopardize my basic needs such as hunger. 
And if I happen to eat garbage, I prefer it to be my favorite kind: ramen noodles and wonder bread bologna sandwiches for instance. And do it behind closed doors away from the public eye.

I went here for the first time on my birthday. I had heard good things and wanted to try somewhere new. I'll start by saying that I liked the concept of this place a lot! I was excited to be able to blend my own kind of shrimp and steak stir fry and it was delicious! But, I have to say the prices were a tad steep for what it is. I was also disappointed that the "krab" was cheap imitation junk. The service was good and because we got there at about 5 on Saturday, we had no wait. I'd go again, but not on my own dime! I like a little more bang for my buck!

I've been to the BBQ several times, and overall I like the idea of the place.  Create your own stir fry?  Chicken, lamb, seafood, vegetables?  Sign me up!  However, the last time I was there, I was a little disappointed.  

The food was fine.  Even if it wasn't, I would be the one to blame, since it was my creation.  They had an Oktoberfest promotion running, and the idea of having bratwurst and cabbage as options for the stir fry was intriguing.  But the overall experience was just awful, and a lot of it had to do with the atmosphere and service.

The place tends to be cramped and loud during the dinner rush, but I was surprised at how busy and loud it was at 9:00 pm.  There was a greasy, sticky feel in the air, and seeing food scattered on the floor, the salad bar, and on the unbussed tables would have been enough to make a squeamish person lose his or her appetite.   Our waiter was a portly gentleman with a scruffy unkempt appearance dressed in his T-shirt drenched with sweat.  His disheveled look was a bit of turn off, but I wasn't concerned since he wouldn't be handling the food.  Later, while standing in line, he just happened to walk past me to the server aisle, breathing heavily, with his eyes darting around suspiciously.  I watched as he poured refills into the glasses from another table, holding the glasses around the rims with his stubby, greasy fingers.  Fortunately, I was drinking a bottled beer that night, but it was an unpleasant sight nonetheless.  Getting that bottle of beer was a challenge in itself - the waiter spent a solid two minutes shoehorning his promotional souveneir mug sales pitch into the conversation while taking our order.  If I wanted 32 ounces of beer, I would have asked for it initially!  At some point in the night, he also managed to spill ice cream all over the floor at the table next to us.  Overall, the service was painfully slow - we didn't get extra bowls when we wanted them, we never received the rice we ordered, I didn't get the glass of water I wanted, and I spent most of the time there waiting for one thing or another.  

I'm not saying I wouldn't go back, but it will be a while, and I will need a good reason when I go.  It would seem the management should be keeping an eye out for these things.

TIP FOR NEW CUSTOMERS:  The sauces tend to be very salty, so be sure to use in moderation.  However, if you don't want your stir fry to be dry, try adding some olive oil from the salad bar or some ice from your table to the bowl before you take it to the cooks.  Be sure to be discreet about it though.

I get why people like this place. Heck, I walked in all primed and ready to like this place. I'm a huge fan of Mongolian grill places - my favorite being Hu Hot, a chain in Iowa. But Bd's just kept failing me over and over. We went over on a weekend night - probably our first mistake - and the place was packed. When your food is cooked to order, and you have to stand in line until it's ready, a busy restaurant means you're going to be standing around, hanging out, for a very long time. 

That's fine - it's part of the experience and I get it. But when they put you next to a huge gong that they ring for birthdays, and there are a lot of birthdays, you'll wind up with a ringing headache to accompany your empty stomach.

Finally, the whole thing was too salty - and it happened twice, with two different sauces. Eventually I gave up and had stuff from the salad bar, which was perfectly fine. 

I love the concept and will probably go back - but only because it's the only place like it in the city. I'm hoping that the saltiness was just a one-night thing and that it was somehow my fault, since that would mean a second visit also wouldn't go awry. I'm also going to try to figure out which nights have infrequent birthday diners. Perhaps a nice Tuesday?

The service was slow and some of the soup bowls were not properly washed. When we told them to refill chicken and fish at the meat sections; they bluntly told us it got over for the day in the kitchen (This was around 8:30pm on a Friday). The food was average.

Went here for their soft opening so maybe I should cut them some slack, but I think I'll just keep it real.  While the concept isn't new - it's new to Pittsburgh.  Here's how it works:

-Get a bowl and go to the buffet style set up
Station 1 - noodles/meat
-Choose noodles (rice noodles, rotini, lo mein)
-Fill it with your choosing of raw "blank" (chicken, beef, scallops, shrimp...)

Station 2 - veggies
-Continue to fill small bowl with additional toppings of veggies (mushrooms, peppers, water chestnuts, etc.)

Station 3 - Sauce
-Pick up a small bowl
-Choose preferred sauce (variety of sweet, tangy, savory, spicy sauces available)

Station 4 - Grill
-Take you bowl of noodles, meat, and veggies and your small bowl of sauce up to the grill
-One of the grillers will take it from you and you stand there as it's cooked and they put it on a plate when it's done and you take it and go back to your table.  

Last stop - enjoy your "made to order" meal

I will say that I enjoyed the food - I had the chili garlic sauce during my first trip up to the buffet stations with chicken and steak and some veggies and then I chose the BD teriyaki sauce with scallops and shrimp on my next round.  I definitely preferred the chili garlic sauce - if you like spice then I think you'll enjoy that.

We ordered a pitcher of Strawberry Sangria and it tasted more like a melted Strawberry Daiquiri - uber sweet with no wine taste at all.  It was the low point of the meal.

They gave us a complimentary dessert - the brownie sundae.  Oh my yumminess - it was huge so we all shared it and couldn't even finish it.  

Overall the experience was good but somewhat generic having been to similar chains before in other cities.  I think it will do well in Pittsburgh initially until the novelty has worn off.

I really used to love this place and it saddens me to give this place 2 stars. 

Pros- with an unlimited bowl you have endless options. You also get complimentary sides: white rice, brown rice, tortillas, and lettuce wraps. 

Cons- quality has gone down while prices have gone up. If it's busy the wait to get your food cooked on the grill can take awhile. The cooks never really do a good job of keeping others stir fry from flying into yours. After this past trip my stomach was so messed up. 

Sadly I think I'll just have to retire this place.

The food at bd's tonight was good. The service though was really subpar. That's pretty hard to accomplish when it really only involves bringing and clearing plates and drinks. I'm not sure if it's because our table was in an out of the way corner or if they were understaffed, but our server was MIA a lot of the evening and when he was around he seemed like he didn't want to be.
Another on of my favorite stops when I return to Cleveland.  Great combinations and ideas.

BZZZZZZ BZZZZZZ *Pick up "Hello, thank you for calling BD Mongolian Grill, this is Bailey, how may I help you?

Me: Hi Bailey, yes I'm driving there now and would like to put my name on the list, there will be six of us dining tonight.

Bailey: Awesome, can I get your name?

Me: Yes, it's Joe, J-O-E

Bailey: Okay, great, and you said six of YINZ will be here?

Me: Yes, six of us, at six.

Bailey: Great see YINZ at six!

Nothing like a true Pittsburgher answering the phone of a new place. We all met at the parking garage, which is a treat, because someone is always late, but this was my friends and cousins taking me out for my birthday and to my surprise everyone showed up on time. Fellow veg and great friend, Jamie was joining us as well. We were all BD Mongolian Grill virgins.

We were seated at 6:06 and Emma, our very nice and VERY PATIENT waitress greeted us with water, and menus, she took our drink orders and we looked over the menu. Well, with the girls chatting and all the guys chatting, we neglected to look over the menu, and continued to socialize. Emma brought over six bowls and explained to us how BD Mongolian works. The first station is noodles and proteins, the second station is vegetables, tofu, and other items, third station is sauces, herbs, and spices. Along the way are other employees to help you out. I chose rice noodles, tofu, mushrooms, water chestnuts, broccoli, and red peppers. My sauces were a mixture of Kung Pow and sweet and sour.

Then it's off to getting your bowl cooked. I handed it over to one of the cooks, who asked if I had any allergies to anything, then proceeded to stir fry my dish in very little oil. After a few minutes of cooking and because it was my birthday, banging the gong, my dish was complete, and I was off to my table. In the mean time, Emma brought  brown and white rice to our table, flour tortillas, and lettuce wraps were also there. I waited for everyone and we all dug in! I have to say, I had no idea I was such a good noodle chef, my dinner was delicious. Everyone was very quiet as we chowed down on some really delicious food. There's a salad bar as well, but I never got near it.

I had joined Club Mongo a few weeks back when I went to the BD Mongolian Grill website so my dinner was free, my total was 2.45, and that was for my drink. Later me and Jamie stayed and had drinks at the bar and watched the hockey game.

BD Mongolian Grill could be my new go to place for lunch or dinner, I really loved the atmosphere, the staff, and Mike, the bartender is very friendly, and goes out of his way to make you feel at home. I LOVE it here!

So I went there for my birthday and each and every time I have had an awesome experience. The staff here are really nice and the "boy grill band" are very attentive and they really know how to put on a show. They sung happy birthday to me twice. The food is always good because I make it and the fried Oreos are always my favorite. The waiter, I believe "Ant" was really nice he was the one with the locs he was really nice also. 

The only thing that I would say was a little off putting was the mess around the food and for a period of time they did run out of sauce cups.  I came with a large party  everyone loved it was well. I can't wait to go back.

I stopped by here a couple of Thursdays ago with fiance for dinner.  I had been wanting to come here for awhile but never made it until my fiance's brother was telling us how awesome Mongolian Grilles were.  The inside of this place looks like what you would expect from a salad bar type restaurant.  Fairly minimal in the decorations with a large area on one side with the food and then a large seating area with a bar on the other side and the Mongolian grill in the back.  The grill did have a gong on it which the cooks encouraged people to ring and there were also ample TV's throughout the restaurant to the point where you could watch one from pretty much anywhere.

For my entree I decided to go with the unlimited bowl.  There are many different choices of what to go with here including about 20 different kinds of meats, 20 kinds of vegetables and 20 sauces or so.  The first time through the line I got the ribeye as my protein with some vegetables and then the garlic chili sauce.  Since I was a rookie at this, I poured my sauce over top of my food instead of in the small cup that I was supposed to.  Whenever I took my food over to the grill to be cooked I got some good-natured ribbing from the cooks about how I had to be new.  My fiance and I also had quite a bit of a wait for our first bowls as the whole grill area was full and so we were two deep.  If there is one complaint that I have about this place, that is it.  Waiting for your bowl can take a while at times and can be frustrating.  However, after my wait my bowl was certainly worth it.  The sauce was spicy as expected and I loved the garlic taste of it and the vegetables and ribeye that I had mixed it with were good as well.  I would eventually end up getting two more bowls, the first as a ribeye with vegetables and a Szechuan sauce and the second as a shrimp with vegetables and a ponzu sauce.  The wait was much shorter the second two times and I have to admit that it was all pretty good and I really enjoyed my meal.  The best part was that I was unable to finish my last bowl and threw in the towel after eating about half of it. Seeing that, that server offered a to go box for me to take home.  Yeah for some free lunch!

The bottom line for me is that I will definitely head back here again in the future and my fiance would as well.  With that being said, I am looking forward to bringing some of my male friends and getting in some good eating.

This is one of my family's favorite places.  The food rocks, I read the review about the soggy vegetables, just ask the cook to leave it on for a little longer if you care that much.  Otherwise it's located in a little college area and the area is great.  Only downside is it's located a little ways from any freeways.

Get some help if you haven't been before, kinda confusing at first, but staff always ready to lend a hand, half the fun is watching them cook on the giant grill, place was clean, restrooms nice, kinda a self serve deal even though you have a server, Long Island ice tea a little light on booze, all in all a good experience

I love this place! Location is really convenient and I like that it's in the works instead of being on Carson. 

How it works: If you choose the buffet your server will bring you a bowl which you can pile as high as you can balance it with anything from the buffet.  Next you take your food to the grill.  Occasionally the line is a little lengthy but definitely worth it.  First your food is placed on the grill, then your sauce toward the end.  When it's all finished cooking it's put on a new plate.

This place definitely has something for everybody! I get a bowl and pile it high with steak, green beans and potatoes.  I love the million options for sauce and seasoning; I make mine extra spicy!
  I brought my grandmother with me for my birthday last month and she opted for a delicious bowl of veggies and chicken.  I brought my extremely picky father with me too, and he ended up ordering chicken fingers which he loved.  My gram and I each got cocktails at the recommendation of our server and they were delicious! 
They've also got really tasty mini deserts!
