Hostess was fast and our server Mike was great! The guys on grill are super friendly and fun, too.

One thing I noticed about another review - Reviewer said she was too short, at 5'4", to see what food was on the buffet.  I'm a full grown woman at 4'9" and I can see just fine, so I'm not too sure about that. 

Overall, I highly recommend BD's.  It's one of my favorite spots in Pittsburgh for a fast and casual meal!

I stopped by here after a bike ride from Millvale to Southside with my wife.  We saw this place in the Pittsburgh enjoy book and liked the idea of a create your own stir fry menu.  We arrived on a Saturday afternoon and were seated right away.  The inside looked like what you'd expect, having a soup and salad bar on one side and the raw meat/veggie/spice bar on the other side.  

We started out at the salad bar, trying each soup.  They had an extremely spicy 4 pepper soup that I loved as well as a root vegetable soup. I really enjoyed both soups; the root vegetable had some flavor in it that I recognized from a pasta that I used to get all the time in college.  It was such a great moment of nostalgia! The salad bar wasn't that impressive.  Only containing your typical lettuce tomato onion mushroom etc with about 6 dressings to choose from.  That was just OK.  

Finally we ate ourselves around to the main course.  Our waitress brought out brown rice to go with our meal so we could fill our plates with whatever meat and veggies we wanted.  I ended up doing a combination of rib eye, chicken, and sausage for my meats. The sausage was by far the best with a good hearty flavor! I ended up adding some corn, beans, and broccoli to my dish as well and my sauce was a little spicy with red pepper, cayenne and Korean bbq.  This combination turned out alright.  

The down side of only having one bowl is that you do not get to make multiple combinations and try things out.  The other option of getting unlimited bowls is tough to control portion sizes given that each cook takes around 10 minutes and at there was a bit of a line to get your food cooked when we were there.  If you're not looking for a quick food experience take your time and enjoy the unlimited bowl here.  Otherwise, a single bowl should be enough to fill you up. Regardless this was a cool experience with decent food!

This place has a pretty gimmicky concept: you get a bowl; fill it up with an assortment of meat, seafood, veggies, spices, and sauce; and then BD's grills it for you. It's kind of fun, but also means that the how well your meal turns out is largely dependent on how good you are at picking out a tasty combination of ingredients. 

The quality of the ingredients generally seems pretty good, but if you don't know anything about concocting a stir-fry, it's easy to end up with something largely inedible--I've seen it happen to friends way too many times. Thankfully, BD's has a set of "recipe cards" you can use to assist you in making something good if you're new to the concept. Still, there's basically nothing here you can't make better at home in your wok.

Service is good, and the guys manning the grill are universally great--they put on a good show, throwing eggs in the air and making you laugh as you wait for your food. Whenever they get a tip, they ring a giant gong. The servers are also pretty good, if a bit slow sometimes. BD's is group-friendly.

Prices generally seem a bit high for what you get--it definitely feels like you're paying for the "fun" concept more than the food. BD's can be a good time, and it's worth trying once, but the food itself just isn't good enough or unique enough to keep me coming back when there's so many other options nearby.

Good quality of meat, fish and vegetables! Great place for a group dinner!

This was my first date night with my boyfriend, now husband of 7+ years, while he was attending CWRU. Great times since then for us! We have taken many family members and friends here, they love it every time! We also had our going away party here (moved to NV at that time)!

This BD's is located in Coventry with various restaurants and stores. Parking is on the street or metered so bring quarters or dimes! I wish they would upgrade to credit card machines. Who carries change these days?! The restaurant itself is on the lower level of the building.

Mongolian BBQ is where you grab your type of meat or vegetables (raw) in a bowl, make a concoction of your own sauce and bring it up to a huge round grill where they cook it for you.

Customer service is usually pretty good. The grill masters are awesome! So friendly! If you tip them, they ring a huge gong! They also sing happy birthday to you if it's your birthday.

Quality of meats and vegetables are great. All fresh! There is an assortment of sauces with index cards used as cheat sheets if you are unsure of what sauces to combine. Last visit I made earlier this year for my trip home seemed a bit off. Not as good as I remember or maybe the sauces were lacking. They used to have tons.

Come here with family and friends, eat your heart out and then head to The Winking Lizard a couple buildings down and have a beer!

Loved this place - the food that is (because I had takeout). You can pick your meat(s), vegetables, and source for your stir fry and they'll make it how you want it. Their pot stickers are the best I've had yet. Will definitely go back.

I'm really excited about what I just experienced. Wait time was a bit long but it's Saturday night and the result was worth the wait. Our servers name was Mike. Mike was awesome despite how slammed it was.

Before I went to BD's Mongolian Grille in the South Side Works, I saw the commercials and watched the videos online, and I got excited. It looked like it would be a hibachi style place with cooks doing tricks and the food being really interesting. What I found was place that was a mix of Benihana and Moe's Southwest Grille, with an all you can eat buffet thrown in.
I actually got dressed up to go to BD's, but I realized quickly that I was over dressed. Again, think Moe's Southwest Grille. I was surprised by the casualness of the restaurant, being that it is in South Side Works and it seemed from what I read that this was an experience restaurant. 
The way it works, is you get a bowl at the beginning, and head up to a big salad bar type set up. From there, you pick from raw ingredients like chicken, shrimp, steak, pork, mahi mahi, and others. I liked all the choices and everything looked fresh, but I have to imagine that the little kid across from me that was using the raw chicken tongs to get raw steak didn't understand what salmonella is. Then, you move on to the raw veggie section that is filled with everything from broccoli, mushrooms, bean sprouts, peppers, onions, and lots more, including a raw egg that the cooks will scramble. Finally, it's on to the sauce cart, which is where the food gets it's flavor. You can choose from a ton of sauces that are sweet, BBQ, hot and spicy, or many others. I tried the peanut sauce which had a slight kick to it but wasn't overpowering. 
Next comes the part that is supposed to be fun- the cooking. You stand at a counter that encircles the round cooking surface where the cooks make your food. This is where the commercials show people throwing food around and doing tricks, but the reality is you stand there and watch the guy take your food and dump it on the grill. After about what seemed like 15 minutes, and a few turns of the ingredients you've chosen, your food is handed back to you to enjoy. Personally, I didn't like that I had to stand there for that long, and what was worse was since they were busy, I had to stand in line for 15 minutes, holding my bowl of raw meats and veggies while I waited for an opening at the counter. By the time I sat down, I spent 30 minutes making my meal and had a cramped hand to show for it.
With that said, the food was good. The ingredients and choices they offer allow for endless combinations, and since you can go up multiple times with the unlimited choice, you could try lots of combinations until you get it right. I also liked the go-withs, like the white and brown rice, tortilla shells, and lettuce leaves (for making lettuce wraps). 
As for their salad bar, I wasn't that impressed. The soups were clam chowder and white bean chili when I was there (are those Mongolian?) and the salad bar seemed pretty standard. I would suggest not filling up with the salad bar and instead go right for the hot food.
In all, I wasn't impressed with BD's, but it wasn't a bad experience. I didn't like the wait time for my food, and the experience makes it hard to enjoy with someone else- you're always waiting for your next dish or building a lettuce wrap to really appreciate anyone around you. Plus, the design and attitude of the staff makes you feel like your at a casual restaurant (again, think Moe's Southwest Grille), so it doesn't feel like a special experience, but more like a gimmicky restaurant. On top of that, they do a good job of discouraging you from going up to make new bowls since there's such a wait time involved. They could have had two grills going, and there still would have been a line.
I was with a large group- some of my friends loved it, and some hated it, but for the most part the food was good and the prices aren't extravagant. Just don't expect a fancy dinner.

Three words: raw meat bar. You can make a squid (ahem, "calamari") burrito if you want, which I did and wouldn't recommend. It tasted fine, but who wants to get to the business end of a burrito and find a tentacle waving in your face? That's the last time I try to impress my four-year-old niece.

This is also the perfect place to go before a rock show in order to pack in valuable protein for the long, long night of drinking and smoking ahead of you.

I have been to this place a few times and its just ok. Nothing special. The meat quality isn't terrific but its passable, the salad bar isn't very impressive or fresh. The price is decently reasonable; not too cheap or not too expensive either. No need to go out of your way to come here.

This is a build-your-own-bowl stir-fry, with an option for unlimited bowls, plus a decent soup and salad bar - all in all, exactly what I was looking for. The appetizers/add-ons are pretty good - we tried the bacon fried rice and the potstickers; in hindsight, just going with the stir-fry bowls would have been better value given that there were just two of us, but a couple appetizers split amongst a group of a few people would be worth it. I'll definitely be making a return trip here!
Excellent selection, so many sauces, spices, meats & veggies to choose from plus a salad and soup bar included - brought with me a Mongolian friend & he loved it too!

Love it!!! But I try not to come here if I plans afterward cuz I never know how my stomach will react to the assault.

For those of you interested, there actually is a trick to this place. Someone taught it to me and now I'm passing it on to you. Save the meat till last! If you've only paid for one bowl and want to make the most out of it, you know that the veggies start to tumble off the side when it gets full. Do your loose, tumbly veg first, fill the voids with the smaller stuff like corn and peas. Don't be afraid to smash things down as you load on more veg. Then when you've got a good mound going and you think it can't hold any more, go back to the meat. Drape those thin moist slices of meat over your bowl like blankets. The meat will stick so you can layer on as much as you want! You'll end up with more of a mountain than a bowl. Combine that with 2 cups of sauce, mix in your whole bowl of rice at the table and you've easily got 2 very filling meals. Fry up your leftovers in a skillet for round 2 a few days later!

Sure the unlimited is only a few bucks more but you can't take leftovers home!

The surprise hit for me is the meatballs. They're so tender and work very well in a stir fry.

Oh, and the lettuce wraps are awesome! Way better than the thick floury tortillas.

Let's put it this way...we practically live next door to BD's and we've only eaten there one time since it opened. 

The food is fine, but since you're sort of on your own to develop your recipe, it kind of defeats the purpose of going out to eat. Don't you want to go out and have a professional chef provide you with his or her palate-pleasing recipe? So BD's does all of the prep work and the actual cooking, but throwing a bowl of stuff on a flat grill and standing there waiting for your food isn't my idea of a great restaurant experience. The chefs hardly entertain, aside from a little banter with the guests. Overall, they just stand there and occasionally flip their "swords" while hoping to not undercook your meat(s)...yawn. 

The positives? The cost and the service. For lunch, at least, it's really affordable. It would be hard to get all of the ingredients and cook at home for under the cost of your meal, but I'm still not sure if that's a good enough reason to go. The service is actually pretty good. The waitstaff, bartender, and cooks all seemed really nice, so you're at least welcomed into BD's with a positive vibe.

I will say the absolute worst part of my meal was the crab rangoons. I'm not sure if they'll make it into the actual menu, but they were awful. The wonton wrapper was so thick and bland that it would've overwhelmed any potential flavor inside of the rangoon. Not to mention the dipping sauce didn't go well with rangoons, either. Totally disappointing; perhaps the only time in my life that I left uneaten crab rangoons behind. 

Overall, the whole experience as average as it gets. I'm sure we'll eventually go again out of convenience, but I haven't thought about going back since our sole visit, and I don't see that changing any time soon.

Really great place to load up on food. It's especially good if you're looking for a small change of pace from the regular types of chain restaurants that are so plentiful throughout America. 

Food was very good. You go through a buffet-style line and then give all of your ingredients to the grill masters who fry it up and hand it back to you. Pretty awesome. I recommend spending an extra $2 to get the unlimited trips. One could really so some damage with that much power. 

I'd go back anytime.
I feel like this place has gone downhill over the years. The salad bar was pathetic and dirty. I'm sorry guys but it's true.

If you have friend who have a wide variety of dietary restrictions, ie  vegan, vegetarian, meat this is probably one of the better places to go.  It can be pricey at night but Wednesday nights they have a special for people with college id's and their lunch price is a bit cheaper.  I've gone there mainly on Saturdays and Sundays for lunch with friends and its either packed or dead. 
The selection for toppings is good and they change it up every so often.  I've never had bad service even when they have been really busy.

BD's Mongolian is a fun place for a group-- what's nice is you get exactly what you want; pick out your meat, pick out your vegetables and sauce, and they grill it on the giant block right in front of you.  If you're hungry, get the all-you-can eat plate, and go back for seconds.  
A salad bar comes with the meal, but why bother? The salad bar is unexception, and instead just pick veggies for your meal.
It's always busy, but usually you get seated immediately.

Very good options for proteins/vegies/sauces and spices.  The staff is pretty friendly.  Also has a salad bar/soup for those who are just tagging along and not into the whole "Mongolian BBQ" thing.  

The prices are absolutely reasonable: $8 for one bowl, $10 for all-you-can-eat.  Go for the 2nd, and experiment with smaller bowls would be my suggestion.

My husband, daughter and I came for dinner which was the first time we had ever been here and the food was great but service was awful.  We sat for over 5 minutes without being greeted so my husband got drinks for us from the bar and a few minutes after that our server showed up but didn't seem interested in us being there.  The restaurant was not busy at all there were a handful of tables around us but being served by other servers.  We ordered my daughters food then got ours and still by this time my daughter never got her apple juice we asked for.  So I went to look for the server to ask her for the juice and a refill on my beverage.  She wasn't attentive at all.  We are not sure if we will be returning. It was a bad experience for first time visitors.

I was just there last week. It was about $15 for all you can eat bowl, I believe just one bowl was $13, so for the $2 extra dollars might as well go for it. Skip out on the appetizers, even for half off during happy hour, wasn't anything special. I took a quick peek at the soup & salad bar and it didn't seem to be worth it either, although I believe it's included in the unlimited bowl, not sure about that though. My other suggestion would be to put your veggies in the bowl first and then pile your meat on top. They have it set up so you do the meat first and then veggies, but I feel like unless you got mad skill, you end up not being able to put as many veggies in your dish and then your meal seems like it's missing something. Also, there's a huge selection of sauces and spices.. I kind of felt like it was overwhelming, because there were so many options and not really anything you could sample them with. So if you're not really sure of what you like or want, it was hard to try and figure out what would be good. I know on the menu they tell you some things that you can mix together for a certain taste, but it's not listed by the sauce section anywhere. First time up our griller was pretty good, but the second time the guy was too busy doing tricks that he didn't turn our food enough and it ended up being slightly burnt on the one side. Oh - what I thought was nice, is the waitress suggested that we get the unlimited for $2 and she'd box it up so we could take it home for lunch. So no matter what, you're taking something home. We went around 5, so it wasn't that crowded yet.. around 6 more people started coming and lines were formed at the tables and grill for a small wait (I know there were a lot of complaints about that when I read reviews about the place). Overall it was a good experience. Would I go back? Probably. I left feeling like it was convenient, something new.. but I felt like I could just make it at home.

Not really big on giving 5 stars. But this place . The food was great. The atmosphere was fantastic. I love this place. Our waiter was on of the best I've ever had. All other waiters will be compared to him from now on. So I feel sorry for them lol. The manager came by a few times to check on us. He even pulled up a stool so my daughter could see her dish being prepared. A must see and visit.

The way this place works is pretty cool. You get a bowl and just stack it with all different types of meat and seafood. The choices were overwhelming but all great. It was interesting to watch them make your creation. For the amount of food you get, the price is good as well. I'll definitely be back.

The idea is so solid, how could it go wrong? If your foods crappy, you only have yourself to blame. One of my all time favs...throw what you like in a bowl, and fire, and do it all over again! And the deep fried Oreos are the real deal!

Absolutely love this place! Although it's a bit of a drive from where I live, I make the trip several times a year including my birthday! I've also held a fundraiser that couldn't have gone any better!

Fun fun fun! Great food too! Reasonable prices. The atmosphere here is great. The music consisted of current songs, the food was fresh, and the restaurant was clean. Located in Southside Waterworks. I appreciated the prices as well. I ate from the buffet and had unlimited soup salad and stir-fry bowls. 
That was too much food although it was only about $13! I would suggest just one stir-fry bowl a salad and soup. The salad bar had a fair amt of toppings to choose from. There were two soup selections. There were 3 stations dedicated toward building your stir-fry bowl. 
You could choose from a variety of noodles, meats, veggies, sauces, and seasonings. You could even add a raw egg to be cooked by the chefs who toss up your bowl mixture at a cooking station that you wait at for your food to get cooked.

I also went there today for the opening..  Serena did a good job with her review.  I noticed lots of people having Sundaes (found out there were a lot of birthdays).   I am from Cincinnati and have been to that location many times along with the one in DC.  

There were a lot of workers (almost too many).  I spoke to several of them and they said they never heard of the place until they got a job there.  They still need to work out the kinks.  For example my waitress didn't know where to get me a knife from and kept taking my glass to the kitchen for an ice tea refill when the bar and an additional beverage station was right behind me.  She also forgot to bring rice and tortillas.  This BD's offers lettuce wraps too.  

Meat/seafood consisted of chicken, ribeye, strip steak, marinated steak, pork, meatballs, shrimp, scallops, maui maui fish, sausage, brats (which looked gross), calamari.

Noodles (rice, rotini, lo mein).  Veggies - interesting they didn't have pea pods like the other BD's.  

They also have a good selection of sauces/spices but not as many as other BD's.  

No reason to order appetizers here since you will get filled up on the meal.  Unlimited dinner which includes soup and salad bar goes for $14.99.

Several people kept telling me - YOU MUST TRY Bd's Mongolian Grill!!  So when my friend had her birthday dinner there, I thought it was a great time to try it out.  Unfortunately, I just wasn't impressed.  

The party was on a Friday night and, of course it was hoppin'!  We were informed as to how the place worked, given bowls to fill, and told to have at it - Meats, Veggies, Sauces.  This is where they lost me.  

The meat... it just didn't look good.  I also didn't enjoy the idea of raw meat sitting out there for people to self-assemble.  Maybe I just worked in the food service industry too long... but eww.  Also, it just didn't look clean.

There were decent vegetables - nothing gross or moldy.  They had tofu!  Thank goodness for tofu!  If it wasn't for that, my meal would have been a disaster.

Finally the sauces.  I will say, they just weren't clearly labeled clearly.  Also it was just messy.  If you don't know flavors, you won't make a successful stirfry.  There were several people at our table who destroyed their meals by incorrectly mixing sauces.

The grill is what sells the restaurant.  They guys that work the grill are efficient, comical, and friendly.  They are my reasoning for giving Bd's 3 stars.  I liked the grill.

Would I return to Bd Mongolian's?  If a friend had a birthday there, yes.  If not, I probably would choose one of the other SouthSide venues for my meal.

I love this place and it is still one of my favorite restaurants to visit when I'm coming home. 

I've never had bad service here, the food options are endless and great. I just recently visited after being away for a few years and o appreciate the changes they've made and even added appetizers. 

I hope they put one in my area eventually!

We really liked this place - huge selection of food, great prices and a great server to boot!

The cooks do sing a bit if you tip them, but more importantly - they ensure that all your food is cooked correctly!

Also - the flavor was fantastic - surely we'd return!

It seems people go one way or the other for this place - I'm gonna have to say that I like this place.  A lot.  I've never had a bad experience here, except maybe a huge need for a nap after stuffing myself to the point of nearly being sick.  The food here is amazing.  If you say otherwise, you probably are putting together the wrong combinations, or have stupid taste buds.

I can't believe I have avoided this place for so long! I don't know what I was thinking, but I can tell you I have been missing out! 

The concept was odd to me at first, but quickly grew on me.  I strategically piled my bowl as high as I could with chicken, steak and veggies.  For sauce, I chose teriyaki and added fresh garlic, ginger, and a little bit of the chili garlic sauce. It was so delicious!  I'm always concerned that places like this will get soggy, but the grilling was great.  I had plenty of food leftover (again, strategically stacked my bowl).  I also loved the salad bar and the soup selection they had was really good. I will definitely be returning!!

I love this place! If you are a person who isn't okay with buffet style this is not the place for you. This place is unique because you choose raw meat and veggies of a buffet, whatever sauce and spices you want and then they cook it in front of you on a huge flat top. You basically pay 1 price for the "bowl" which is endless. They cook whatever you can fit in your bowl and when you finish, head back to make a new one! They also have a kids menu. Standard ambience, nothing special. Patio seating available. Service is quick even when they are very busy. I have been here several times and will return.

This is my all time favorite restaurant. There is not one near me now so when I go home to Cleveland I insist on visiting. If you do not like the food here it is generally your fault because you pick out exactly what you want, put it in a bowl and the grillers make it for you. I have several different combinations I love and last time I was home they added some Italian options which made the whole experience even better. This is just a fun place to go.
Great food! Great service!  Small restaurant. Tables are too close. Limited walking area between tables.

After a bicycle ride, this was a great spot to dine outdoors and have a nutritious and filling meal.

After the server's guidance, we promptly piled on the protein and veggies, picked from an assortment of sauces and mixed them with others, and proceeded to the preparers who mixed it all up on the grill, doing what they do best.

Scrumptious.

Tip:  Pile it up high in the bowl given you because it does shrink in size when cooked.

Very fairly priced.

Service was good Atmosphere was nice. You do wait for your food for a little while longer then you should. But other then that I like everything huge portions of food ! & food was delicious #Yum I had the black salmon salad and the shrimp scampi my boyfriend had the Asian salad and the hot spicy chicken sandwich and Sty fry  all of it was
Never had food poisoning in my life but thanks to this place I did. Never been more sick from food. Don't go, definitely not worth it.

We were introduced to Mongolian BBQ several years ago. We were so excited when this restaurant opened. It is my boys favorite place to eat and they would eat there every day. When it opened I really loved it but each time we go it seems to go down hill. I can't put my finger on any one big thing but just little things. The quality of meats is inconsistent. The cleanliness of the bathrooms is "iffy". The service is hit or miss. 
Today we went during Happy Hour. Appetizers and beers on tap are half off. Specialty drinks are $2 off. I put in an order for Crab Rangoon. Fifteen minutes later the waitress told us they were out. She asked if I wanted something different. I said that the other two things I liked had pork in them and due to health issues I couldn't eat pork. She left and then came back and said the had shrimp and artichoke wontons. When they came they weren't good. It was all flavorless artichoke mashed up. There was no sign or taste of shrimp. There was no dipping sauce to help bring flavor. 
I made a plate of ad libbed a version of Pad Thai. The grill area was packed so it took a long time for my food to be cooked. There were five of us in our party. Two of us only ate one bowl. The other three ate two bowls each. All of the guys liked their food but thought the wait to get it was too long. 
It's definitely a place you have to try once but it will be awhile before I go back.

This place is AWESOME.  I live in CA now and WISH we had these out here.  The Mongolian BBQ place here (Genghis Khan) sucks compared to BD's.

You make your own dinner buffet-style....get your own meat, veggies, oil, sauce, spices.  Bring your bowl to the grillers and they cook it for you.  On your table will be steamed rice, tortillas, soy, & hot sauce.  If your dinner sucks, guess what....it's your fault, you made it!  Go try another combo then.

The only bad part about this place is that it's usually busy, so expect to wait.  Otherwise this place rocks.  Also a good place to take a first date.

Letter grade:  A
My family with three young children have eaten here twice. The staff are super nice to my kids and we love that each kid gets a personalized favorite meal.

This place is awesome! It is slightly pricey so my advice is fill your bowl to the max, because going a second time is 3 additional dollars, and if you go a second time and want to take left overs home its an additional 3 on top of the 3. SO that being said go once fill it to the max and take left overs home all for 1 price. 

The only thing I don't like about this place is cross contamination. I dont have any allergies, so I had nothing to worry about. But I can see someone with allergies having serious issues here. 

The restaurant is huge and clean, the staff is friendly and joyful. I had a lot of fun here, I defiantly recommend this place.

Being in a popular location, they don't have to put much effort into getting good business.  This is reflected in their cleanliness. I went to a BD's in Columbus that was EXCELLENT, this one however... Upon arrival the buffets looked like a ravenous kindergarten class had been through there. It was never once cleaned during my 90 minutes there. Every meat and seafood juice was all over the bar and ladel handles. Every ingredient was scattered into every other ingredient. The grill was never fully cleaned so each bowl came with a heavy helping of burnt leftovers from previous cooking. Finding a "clean" bowl at the buffet was a challenge as every other bowl was covered in food (bad dishwashing) thereby spoiling the bowls on top and below them. It took about 10 minutes for my stomach to start revolting against what I had done to it, and I spent the next 50 minutes of my drive home clenching my cheeks. If this review saves just one person from the agony I am enduring, then this review was worth writing.

Always love coming here!!! The salad bar is great!!! You have to get the Wam Bam Shrimp, and Egg rolls to share!!! And the 'create your own stir fry' station with all the different sauces is genius!!! 

The stir fry is great because you can always create something different on every visit, since there are so many different options for the meat lovers, or vegetarians, or even the best of both worlds....and did i just see TOFU...hey somebody will eat it!!! And of course, if you have a little tummy room leftover, theres dessert!!! Brownie, ice cream... thank you!!! 

I always have to take home leftovers, which is always good for lunch for dinner the next day!!!

The staff is always attentive, and watching them cook the stir fry is always entertaining!!! 

Definitely a Must if youre in the Coventry area!!!

Stopped here on a whim for a late lunch and we weren't sure what to expect. We were pleasantly surprised. It is a little overpriced but the food/ options are amazing. We tried the jalape√±o mozzarella sticks which were a nice little chance. We each got a bowl and filled it with meats, shrimp, veggies, noodles... Everything. This is a great place for picky eaters. You get to choose exactly what you want in your plate. 
The service was good. The waiter was vet friendly and the grill cooks were entertaining. We will definitely be back and recommend this to anyone.
Might as well just take some exlax and save some money. The ingredients just sit at room temperature for hours...sort of disgusting.
Great spot to eat.  Create your own meal and they cook it.  Reasonably priced for all you can it.

I've been eating at this joint since it opened, but tonight's experience left me unhappy and unsatisfied.  First, this place is just straight up sticky and dirty.  I didn't want to touch anything!  Seated punctually, but it took a waitress about 10 minutes to come to our table to take our drink order.  She was very nice though.  The beer selection is fairly limited, got a Blue Moon, but it was room temperature and tasted flat.  Yuck!!  Did the customary, walk through the line to get your fixings, and it was dirty and sticky and they were completely out of the meat I wanted.  Some of the veggies looked like they'd been sitting out for hours, wilted and dry appearing.  The spice area was so messy, sticky and dirty, I wished someone would just wipe it up as they pass by it.  The stir fry was cooked well and everything tasted alright.  It's just hard to have a good dining experience when you barely want to touch the menu or your table!  The quality of this place has taken a dive, won't be back for a while.

Review 1: 5 star, second visit

This is not so much a review, but a how to guide on getting the most for your money. Step 1. Join mongo grill rewards and receive $5 off. Step 2. Go for lunch and get the unlimited bowls and soup/salad. Step 3. Get 2 bowls with tortillas as they come separate. Step 4. Eat the unlimited soup and salad for lunch. This means that you get 3 meals for about $3 a piece. The key is, they will only give you one to go box. 

Review 2: 4 star, first visit

I really like the concept of creating your own bowl, it makes for a fun food experience and allows the ability to go multiple times and never eat the exact same dish. I have always liked this type of food for a  new relationship type dinner as it allows you to see what your significant others food preferences are and it opens up good conversation about food likes and dislikes. 

Moving onto the review, this was my first time at this chain place. I have always gone to Ghengis grill chain and I prefer Ghengis because they allow you to pick a small medium or large bowl vs BDs which only gives you one option. BDs only gives you the option for rice or tortillas and pasta is considered a meat and must fit into your bowl. At Ghengis they allow you to choose from rice or pasta as your starch and doesn't count towards filling your bowl. 

That being said, the food was good. I did the create your own and my friend ordered off the menu. Ordering a dish off the menu deprives from the experience and just makes this place an average stir fry restaurant. I suggest the create your own. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was to open concept. It had a fast food seating type environment that took away from the experience. I would prefer more sectioned off seating. 

I would rate it 3 stars due to the seating, and the lack of pasta as your starch adder, but I really like the concept, so 4 stars

It was ok. Don't think it was worth 12.59 for one bowl and a soda. Maybe it was my seafood choice ? I might try it one more time with meats n see. But for now I'm ranking this as just OK for Mongolian BBQ
My favorite mangolian grill place in Pittsburgh that I've been too. I've been there many times. Considering the price the quality is pretty good but they are not consistent with the ingredients.

This wasn't my first time here but I figured it's time to finally write a review. The concept is really good here, but things can easily go array. The concept is simple you fill up your bowl with as much meat/seafood and veggies as your heart can desire then you take it over to a huge circle grill and watch it be prepared in 5 minutes. I don't know why, but it seems like in your head you think you've made the best combination possible but it is never quite as good as you hoped it would be. I am guilty of using too much beef last time when trying to make a teriyaki style combination and the flavors were too overpowered. This is a fun place to come for first timers, but there are better options around. 

Minus another star because the service never seems to be very good, ever.

Having lived in Dallas for some time and being a frequent diner at the Genghis Grill, I was tickled to hear that a Mongolian grill was FINALLY coming to Pittsburgh.  My PIC (Partner In Cuisine) and I rushed down there the first week they were opened and we were not disappointed.  They have a great variety of meats, veggies, carbohydrates (pasta, rice, tortillas), and spices that you can put together in any combination and then have the guys at the stir fry cook it up for you eating pleasure. 

Since my PIC and I obviously spend a lot of time together and dine out VERY frequently, it never occurred to me that there is one huge problem with the place.  If you're looking for a place to have a nice, chill dinner to catch up with a few friends or are going out with a larger group, this is NOT the place to go.  If it's busy, there is a good chance you will find yourself waiting in line for your food to be cooked for upwards of 10 minutes so if you don't time getting your food just right, you might find yourself with your food being half eaten while your companions are still waiting for theirs to be cooked.  If you go for your second bowl, you could seriously turn what might have been a 45 minute meal into an hour and a half if you and your companions don't coordinate accordingly.  The motif of the restaurant does not really work logistically .

All of that said, if you're looking for a decent meal with nothing deep fried with someone you can coordinate your food selections / cooking, it's an awesome place.  

P.S.
Wander around the  South Side Works and you're likely to find one of the employees handing out $2 off coupons that you can use for each person in your party!

Carry out - this review applies to the carry out experience.  Ordered one of the stir-frys.  Cost a little over $13 and was a tiny portion.  Smaller than you would expect for an appetizer.  Literally went back out to a different restaurant after finishing it.  The dish wasn't especially good either.  Was very disappointed with the experience.  After discussing this experience with others, apparently the in restaurant experience is quite a bit better.  Just avoid the carry out apparently.

I stopped into BD's with some friends late Saturday night for a quick bite. We originally wanted stir-fry, but we didn't order it because a bowl cost $15 (we're all on college student budgets). I guess the high price is because you get unlimited soup and salad with it. We were told soup and salad alone cost $7.99. Apparently, you can't order stir fry without the unlimited soup and salad. To me, that's not that great of a deal. I ordered some fried rice and potstickers instead. They were pretty yummy, but nothing to write home about. I've had better at other Chinese spots. 

This place is nice for a quick bite to eat, but I don't think I'll be going out of my way to eat here.

I hit up the place after a friend recommended it.  The place was kind of hard to find as you will have to enter into a door that reads, "McNulty's" In any case, the atmosphere is pretty crazy.  There were TONS of people there (which is a good sign because that means the food is good); took us about 20 minutes to get seated.  The only bad thing that I have to say about this place was that the wait staff and bar tender (who I think was having an ESPECIALLY bad day) were all pretty rude.  I can't completely fault them, because the place was a total mad house with SO many people there.  The Mongolian Chefs were fun, the food is pretty much picked out by yourself so if it's bad...then you're the one to blame.   I also had to knock it down one notch because due to the amount of people my food ingredients were mixed in with some other peoples (I can't stand shrimp!)
Over all, it is worth the trip for the experience!

Good food + prices when up and the food seemed watered down last time I when.
The cooks are funny it's a cool restaurant

I've come here a couple of times, since it's just a few blocks from my college. There's definitely a wide array of different dishes available here, but you will have to assemble them yourself and the flavors can be hit or miss depending on your skill! They do offer some suggestions or "recipes" if you don't want to be too adventurous. Sauces range from BBQ to marinara and everything in between and a huge variety of meats and vegetables are available as well. 

After you pile on all of your ingredients into a bowls and select your sauces, you go to the circular grill in the center and hand the ingredients to the cook. They are very good at accommodating vegan and vegetarian restrictions and separating your food from that of surrounding customers! 

The service is usually pretty light since everything is basically make-your-own and waiters are sometimes hard to come by. Pricing is a bit high (at around $15 for a make your own bowl/plate) but you can definitely heap mounds of food on the bowl if you try! Street parking is a bit difficult, but there is cheap metered parking in a lot across the street. 

Overall, I'd say this place is definitely good for an occasional meet up with friends, but the high pricing is a bit of an issue.

I love BD been a long time customer since they first open a place in royal oak Michigan.   Every location serves the same top notch quality food.  You take a bowl fill it with meats, veggies and add sauce.  Take it up to the grill they cook it for you.  Great atmosphere, friendly waiters and grillers you can't go wrong it's the best value around.

I'm afraid this isn't the most sanitary restaurant to visit, so eat here at your own risk! Judging by the color and consistency of the food, particularly the meats, at the raw bar, I suspect there isn't much turnover here. Furthermore, I saw a lot of children serving themselves and expect the risk of contamination to be high. 

As for the wok, the cooks prepared the food well, but I think it would be a lot safer if the raw bar could be positioned much closer to the grill where it can be monitored and replenished as needed.

I did not even attempt to eat any of the sauces at the bar because many seemed to be thick or mayo-based, which does not hold up well to Mongolian stir fry.

There aren't any other Mongolian grills in PGH to my knowledge (aside from the ones at Chinese buffets), so likely most people end up settling here.

My visit this time around wasn't as good as it has been in the past but I can't deny that hearing a grown man sing Katty Perry's "Roar" threw the  bathroom walls  is hilarious! And my sister & I really appreciated the men working the grill, they were very understanding of her vegetarian needs & my food allergies and did not fail to deliver great food and good customer service. 
  They sang along with almost every song as well which added to the fun & experience of my visit. I just wish they offered more vegetarian/vegan/gluten- free options and that the location was handicapped accessible.

I have been to BD's a handful of times.  Every single time has been an interesting experience.  You learn tricks from other people about "how to fill your bowl" and "put noodles on top", etc  

My past experiences have been nothing to write home about.  They have not been terrible - but not been great.  Just - Ok.  One time we had overly burnt food you couldn't eat.  One time we had under cooked chicken.  

But this last visit was - interesting to say the least.  When my mother visits - she loves to go to BD's.  So on Sunday evening - off we went.  There was probably about 8 other tables in the restaurant filled - one was a HUGE party (Probably 10-15 people).  Our waiter quickly came over, got our drink order and asked about the extra rice/lettuce/etc with our single serving bowls.  Once we had gone up, gotten our food, had it cooked - the large party had left.

We were seated RIGHTBESIDE the door - aka the hostess stand.  There were about 3-4 employees standing around - swearing, yelling across to the bar, etc.  This was really disruptive to our meal.  To make it even better though - The Manager.  This man was RUDE.  He was yelling at employees about how many tables they had, why they weren't cleaning their tables off, etc.  Our waiter - a Gentleman whose name I forget - was rushing around taking care of pretty much all (down to about 6 filled tables now) the tables.  He was more disruptive than anyone in the restaurant.  The different hostesses were too busy flirting with friends, hanging on friends, etc.  There is a time and place for that - at WORK is not it.  

The only plus side to the staff - was our waiter.  That poor guy (seemed to be the only male waiter) was hustling butt.  I heard about one girl only having 1 table to take care of, another girl had to clean off her table - but our waiter (I heard from the manager who was yelling at everyone) had 6 tables at one point.  I could point out that he put our rice on a different table - but I didn't care.  He got us drink refills in a timely manner, got us new rice, got us our bill quickly, etc.  He was amazing in comparison to the rest of the mess happening.  He even apologized for the bad service.  The bad service did not come from him - and it reflected that in his tip - it came form everyone else in the restaurant.  

BD's - get some new management, new hosts, and some reliable wait staff.  But look at your schedule for Sunday evening (7p) March 19th - the tall, younger male waiter - did a great job.  Keep him.  Not the others.

In Chicago we had a place just like BD's that was delicious and not a chain so I'm a little jaded.

PROS:
1. I'm a cook so I consider part of the fun trying to mix up the sauces in a way that tastes good. (My husband SUCKS at this so if you're not so sure you can use one of their recipes. I consider this "cheating.")
2. They have a million different meats! At my old place, they had the usual suspects (chicken, steak, etc.) plus a special. Shrimp was extra although you got great big shrimp. Here you get your choice of like 15 proteins although the shrimp are miniscule. 
3. You get a separate bowl of rice. Yum!

CONS:
1. I think it's the menus, but it feels so chain-y. I hate all the silly language and promotions. There are no booths. The chairs are all those borrowing brown sticks. I feel like I'm at Applebee's. I just want to eat my bowl and be done. I hope nobody hits the gong while I'm here...
2. You have to stand there and wait for your bowl?!? Seriously? You can't just bring it to my table. What are you paying these waiters for? I can think of several systems to allocate bowls to tables to assist you with this process if I'd rather enjoy the company of my dining partners than watch the "magic" of the chef.
3. The focus seems to be on the meat. I think there could be a wider selection of veggies. Where is the bok choy and spinach and tomatoes and...?

This was a different experience,  they have stations with different kinds of meat fish and a vegetable station and spices . Your suppose to get a bow,l go to each station pick the ingredients you want take it to the cooks and then they cook it for you while you wait dosent take long.  They have an all you can eat option . And I was surprised the waitress told us we could take a meal home she gave us a box.

In order to enjoy this place, you need to follow the following rule

1) go on wednesday - it is way cheaper on wednesday and if you can eat a lot, that's money
2) go with a friend who knows how to cook
The quality of the food depends almost entirely on how well you choose your sauce and spices. I have tried at least 6 different combinations till I found my favorite one! obviously I didn't know how to cook haha

food selection - meat option is very generous, from poultry to pork to beef to seafood (scallop, shrimp, fish, etc.). Vegetarians can also find plenty options!
The chefs are amazing! From time to time, they will do a little "performance." I.E. if you have an egg that you would like them to stir fry in, they will crack the egg in a really fancy way by throwing them up real high then drop the eggs right on their long mixing metal thing. It was pretty cool. Sometimes they fill your plate from the back, which was pretty awesome too. You can choose to leave some tips if you would like.

I recently took a weekend road trip to Boston, and on one of the evenings, I was invited to my partner's cousin's birthday party, which was where I experienced my first Mongolian Grille. I'd seen the low-rent Hibachi's at the local Asian Buffets, but this particular experience was totally new to me, and actually VERY cool and fun. The place had a HUGE buffet of 'parts' from noodles and meats, to veggies and sauces, that at first was quite intimidating if you had no idea what you were doing, but I soon got the hang of it, and found a concept I loved.

Upon returning to da burgh, I was telling a co-worker who lives on the South Side about the experience, and she told me that there was a place like that on the South Side. When I got excited, she stopped me and said 'Do NOT try to compare it to your experience in Boston (she knows me too well).

So, after a Sunday morning and early afternoon grocery run and thrift store hunt, after hitting the Goodwill on the South Side, a friend and I decided to give the place a try.

Annnnnnd...my co-worker was right. Boston did it right, Pittsburgh did its usual half-assed version.

Let me start by saying that Boston was staffed mostly by Asian people (Mongolian or not, I don't know, but a theme is a theme). The grill team was VERY engaging with the clientele, the options were mind boggling, and the price for all-you-can-eat was about the same as the price for a one-time trip in Pittsburgh.

The options in Pittsburgh were much more limited, the extent of the 'engagement' from the one-man grill team was 'Do you have any food allergies?', after which his eyes were partially glued to the Stiller game (along with the majority of the rest of the staff - those who weren't staring at their phones and clicking away at texting), and partially to the piles of food he was only half-heartedly mixing on the grill. And there was one single Asian waitress.

When I got to the table, the food was cooked...the pinch of cilantro I selected was all in one clump on that side, the sauce was barely there at all (most of it had been scraped into the waste hole in the middle of the grille) and I basically ended up with a slightly modified chicken pad thai for the usual price of a buffet. 

Along with the single-serve comes unlimited soup and salad, but all of that was included in the all-you-could-eat in Boston, and the burgh version was MUCH smaller. The soups were some tomato something or other, and the chicken soup, which boasted of it's creaminess, looked like chicken noodle soup with some milk poured into it.

If you hit Boston at any point, I highly recommend trying FiRE & iCE! (no typos there, that's how they spell it) and see what the real deal is like. I especially suggest this for all of you Pittsburghers who just firmly believe that Pittsburgh IS 'all that'...experience first rate, and see how silly you really are for raving about mediocre.

My co-worker was absolutely right - do NOT try to compare offerings in da burgh with things you experience in other real cities. Pittsburgh MAY have 'everything'...but they only have ONE of everything that's outside of the beer guzzling, fries on a sandwich varieties. And since they only have 'one' of each, those 'ones' don't really have to try too hard...since most Pittsburghers never know the difference anyway.

And thus...mediocrity reigns supreme.

BD is an ok 'example' of a Mongolian Grill...but only a pricey example...not a full demonstration. I wouldn't say 'avoid it'...I would suggest experiencing it once...and then take a road trip and reach for the stars!

Oh...and seriously...if you're going to theme it...turn off the damned football games! Every bar full of drunks on the South Side already offers that.

I was actually really disappointed. 

I've gone to a few other restaurants that are "Mongolian BBQ" and was knocked off my feet from the service to the food.  Here not so much.  

Honestly, I won't be going back and here is why.  I don't get grossed out too easily but I went over to the salad bar, excited about this option only to be let down.  I made my salad and loaded it with a bunch of goodies... Sat down and started eating only to find glass in my salad.  I told the waiter, he went to check it out.  Now I can't tell you where at in the salad bar it came from but it was there and I instantly shut down.  It took the waiter 20 minutes to come back to me and finally "apologize" and inform me that the workers in the back said it was from a few days ago when they broke something in the salad bar.  My assumption? The salad materials were old.  

Moving over to the food... there was a dead fly in the shrimp. Who knows what else could be found over there but I wasn't taking my chances.

The wait staff was friendly for the most part, until I had my 2$ off coupon for a bowl.  They weren't pleased to honor it.. they did though.  But you'd think after having glass found in your food, they'd be a little happier to honor a coupon or hell maybe throw in a free app to give me an incentive to want to come back... no. 

That's all.  Won't be going back.

This place is hilarious - the most Mongolian thing about it are the two (count 'em, two) large, framed posters of Mongolian persons with hawks on their arms.  Oh yeah, that and the terrible - in a good way - Mongolian puns on the menu, such as a cocktail selection that will help you "Khan-trol your thirst."

Other than that, this is a basic build-your-own-grill plate joint, except they have a large selection of Asian-flavored and Mexican sauces, and the grillers are situated behind a large gong that guests may hit at their pleasure.  And you can make it healthy (or not) as you wish.  The one complaint I would have is that it is a tad overpriced.

Great Happy Hour with $3 Margaritas!!! Available Frozen or on the Rocks in a ton of flavors
Prickly Pear, Watermelon, Blood Orange, Strawberry, Huckleberry, Pomegranate, Raspberry, Ginger, or Sriracha

I'm a huge fan of BD's. I used to go out there more often back in my college days, but still make it out a few times a year.

Basically you get an empty bowl and walk down a buffet of fresh ingredients. The selection of meats, veggies, sauces, and spices is awesome. You pile it all into a bowl and then take it to the grill where the chefs cook everything up on the spot.


You can pretty much make whatever you want and then go back and make something totally different on your next trip. Spicy, sweet, seafood, beef, vegan....it's all there. Add the rice and tortillas and I'm not sure how you can go wrong.

The chefs used to really put on a show, but it's pretty boring these days. Coventry is a super hip little town to hang out in as well.

Great food. Great service. The grill master was fantastic. They were great about keeping up with the lunchtime rush too. I will be back next time I'm in Pittsburgh. Prices are also good.  Unlimited stir fry for 12.99!
Been here a few times. Enjoy the selection of meats, veggies, and spices. Essentially do it yourself style place, but helps if people in your group are more picky!

I am not a fan of this concept, though the prices are reasonable if you know how to load up your bowl to maximize the protein compared to carbs and veggies.  The open containers of raw meats, poultry and seafood at the self serve salad bar-style stations grossed me out.  It just did not seem sanitary.  Thankfully, I ate my concoction and did not get ill.  I will not be back.

This place is brilliant. Choose your meats, choose your vegetables, choose your sauce, and then have it cooked in front of you. Good beers on tap and decent sized televisions for the game. I will be back for sure.

There's not too many times I've resolved to never return to a restaurant but my experience was awful. The quality of the ingredients is horrible. Everything just tastes like canned sh*tty vegetables. The price is exorbitant considering the quality. The only question we had for the waitress was whether we requested rice with her now or up at the grill. She said something along the lines of "oh wherever." The staff balked when I asked someone to refill the brown rice. They visibly argued in front of us about who's job it was and that neither were going to do it. It took ten minutes to be filled. Our table was sticky. The waitress literally struggled to pick up our receipt after she set it down. My unsweetened ice tea was the only thing I enjoyed about my forty minute experience here. Will never make the mistake of coming back here.

So the consensus is: if you don't like it here, you probably just picked the wrong ingredients. Should that matter? How about the fact i'm paying ten dollars to eat a bowl of soggy vegetables. That i had to stand in line to cook. I don't get the appeal. It's a nice place, nice crowd, nice bowls. But the quality of the food is really overrated. Oh, one time a friend found some glass shards in her food. Is that traditional Mongolian, or some Asian-Cedar Ave alleyway fusion thing?
Not bad at all. Really just depends on your choices. Don't skip on the spice section. Ask for Nick as a server :)

I had been dreaming of this place opening in Pittsburgh for years.  I had a girlfriend who worked at the one in Michigan and she guided me through the tricks and treasures of Mongo (as they call it, I know, I'm so "in").  

We ordered a pitcher of sangria because sharing is caring folks!  I was very excited about it because I felt in the mood for something fruity and refreshing, something a sangria should be like.  This was not.  This was strawberry soupy-ness mixed with some alcohol.  It was not good.  I'm not sure if this was something the new bartenders made wrong or it's just the way they make it.  Just be warned:)

I was so the pro, I knew to not pile a bunch of meats into the bowl and I knew to pile that bowl high because it shrinks once it's cooked.  So I get my mix ready:shrimp and scallops, pad thai noodles, lots of veggies and a crap load of water chestnuts because who can resist those!  I choose the Bd's teriyaki the first round and the Kung Poa the second.  The teriyaki fell flat but the Kung Poa was just the right mix of spicy and sweet I was looking for.  

For the grand finale we were brought out this massive glass full of ice cream, one massive brownie (that could really pass for a large piece of cake) whipped cream and fudge.  Holy bajebus it was huge!  But it was seriously massively delicious.  You absolutely have to split it or you may have to be rolled out.  

The thing is, I think my palate has changed.  There's so many wonderful local unique Pittsburgh restaurants that offer such fantastic fresh food, it's hard to keep up when you're a chain.  Don't get me wrong, I'm sure this won't be the last time I go there or the last time I go to a chain, but it just isn't the same...and I think that's probably for the better.

The idea is a good one in theory:  Make a bowl of food exactly the way you want it, and have fun doing it.  In reality, for $14 a plate, I'd rather have a chef who knows what he/she is doing do it for me.  

As it turns out, the bowl I made for myself was good, but not great.  I'm sure if I went there 10 more times and learned about the various sauces I could do a much better job.  But for $14 a try, that's just not going to happen.

It's a pretty easy going restaurant. Unlimited Salad bar with two soups. You can order appetizers. Get there before 7pm for $5 cocktails and $3 apps. 

You get a bowl to fill with raw meats, veggies and noodles. You add your own seasoning and sauces. Add a lot of sauce because when it's cooked they don't add anything and the food dries out fast. You can have unlimited bowls but can't take left overs with that. You can have white/brown rice, tortillas and lettuce leaves to share at the table. 

I would give it a lot more stars except it's always crowded, the tables & floors are sticky. But our waiter was exceptional and made the whole visit awesome.

Wasn't really sure what to expect - as I had never heard anything good or bad about the place. I really liked the concept. I would best describe it as a "Create your own hibachi bowl". The food was amazing, and I feel like if it wasn't - it's your own fault since you picked what went into it. I love that they have scallops and can load up with as much of whatever you want. At some places I think they don't put enough protein in and too much veggies, or vice versa. We also go some appetizers (the spinach artichoke rangoons) which I wasn't as happy with as I thought I would be. They seemed a little too greasy. The service was ok, but they weren't too attentive and they didn't really make the salad bar/food bar very clear at first. Was very good, though.

My whole family enjoys BD's food, prices and atmosphere. Always a favorite choice with my teenage son and 5 year old son. Mongolian's chefs cook on a stone slab grill infront of you while tossing and serving with steel swords, always entertaining. If you enjoy the food be sure to bang the gong and everyone cheers. While you wait at the grill side service bar, chefs will entertain you by playing connect four, rockem sockem robots and more with you or your children. They also have a few song n sword type skits they tend to break into. They are allergy safe, so mention if you have a food allergy and they will take care of you.  There are soo many food options available on the raw bar, almost any type of meat and seafood you can think of, tons of pastas, veggies, spices and more there is also a salad and soup bar, you can use their recipes or create your own, then take to the chefs for preparation. Best part, if you dont like it...try again, its all you can eat!
Love watching them do tricks as their cooking the food. Also you can choose what you want and watch them cook in front of you. Even though they are new to me I do love their food and would come back.
Been there twice, a big fan of the mongolian bbq. Food was great, you create it they grill it. A bit pricy, but had fun and enjoyed teh food.

Always great food and the guys working the grill seem to be enjoying their job every time we are here. They always take great care of our kids and are willing to do things that seem so little like making a lone egg for my 5 year old picky eater. 

We have been here a number of times with our kids and always have a great time.

This was my first visit to BD's and it was a great time!  The waitress started us of by asking if we had every eaten there before and when we said no, she provided an indepth explanation of how to proceed!  Since it operates sort of as a buffet but also as a live cooking experience it can be a bit overwhelming to new comers, but she did a fantastic job of giving us directions.

We took our bowls to the food line and began to make our selections.  The food looked fresh and good, which is a plus!  We filled our bowls with a wide assortment of meat, fish and veggies and selected our flavorings.  The cook was great too!  He cooked our food with flair and we watched as he spun his cooking utensils around with some skill.

Once the food was grilled we found it all to be tasty and wonderfully grilled.  The waitress stayed on top of things and kept our drinks filled as soon as we emptied them.  I really, REALLY enjoyed the experience!

BD' s is a buffet with a stir fry twist. You fill up a bowl with meats, noodles, veggies and top it off with seasonings and sauces of your choice or follow a recipe that they created. There's also a salad and soup bar. They have large sweet specialty cocktails and frozen drinks as well as menu specialties like fried rice. It's the perfect place for picky eaters and to bring kids.

This is easily the most fun buffet style food. Get a bowl, stack it high with a variety of ingredients (anything - meat loaded, vegetarian, vegan), pick a sauce, and you have a personalized stir fry. Although I'm an omnivore I love making a vegetarian bowl - edamame, red and green peppers, bean sprouts, red onion, snow peas, broccoli, chickpeas, black beans, zucchini and yellow squash, noodles, and Thai peanut sauce. That with a bowl of brown rice is always plenty of food for me so I've never even looked at the salad bar. Bartenders and servers are all friendly and attentive, food has been great every time.
Amazingly awesome place. Found this place on my trip to Pittsburgh wishing and waiting for one to come to buffalo.

I have been here just once, I must say I have never seen anything like this before. They had a wide range of food items for the buffet. The interesting part, they cook what you select from the buffet right in front of you on the grill. The food tastes really good. Good ambience, moderately priced. I would recommend this place for dinner.

Awsome food and reallly great prices all you can eat is 12 bucks the have great service cocktails are good my wife and I went today got multiple trips to the buffet multiple take home boxs 2 cocktails each 2 appetizers and dessert for 69 bucks
